HEADLINE: Tired of Mowing the Grass? Just Replace It With a Pool

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY

 BODY:
MARGARET MILLER of Houston turned 50 last year and to celebrate, she said, she had a ''mud pit'' dug in her backyard. ''I'd always wanted a pool, and I thought, you know, I'm old enough, I can have a pool,'' said Mrs. Miller, a Webmaster for the human resources department at Exxon Mobil. 
 The mud pit was the first phase in the construction of her rectangular lap pool, which has three fountains arching across it. The 8-by-20-foot pool replaced a barren spot in the yard where Mrs. Miller said she had spent years fruitlessly trying to coax Bermuda grass to grow. Now she swims laps evenings and weekends but says she most enjoys ''floating face up, looking at the sky and trees.'' 
 She is not alone. More homeowners are building pools of various sizes for exercise and relaxation as well as to enhance their homes' aesthetics and overall value. 
 The National Spa and Pool Institute, a trade organization in Alexandria, Va., reports a 5 percent to 6 percent year-over-year increase in pool construction since 1998. And pool builders and consultants say lap pools are particularly popular because they can be wedged into smaller spaces than the traditional kidney-shaped pool with the diving board at the end. 
 Though many people would not be satisfied with a pool shorter than 40 feet, laps of a sort are possible in 20-foot pools, and those a mere 10 feet long can be outfitted with special jets or harnesses for swimming in place. 
 Tight urban environments and crowded suburbs offer little room for anything much bigger than a lap pool, said John Romano, president of All American Custom Pools and Spas of Norwalk, Conn. Homes are often built so close to the edge of the lot that ''you can literally spit in your neighbor's window,'' he said, adding that his crew recently had to dig a 15-by-30-foot lap pool for a customer in Brooklyn by hand because there was no room between the house and the property line to accommodate even the smallest backhoe. 
 That was a costly project. With all the manual labor and extras like fiber-optic lighting and a computerized filtration system, the Brooklyn pool cost $330,000. But pools can be built in the range of $20,000 to $50,000, Mr. Romano said. It is a price homeowners seem willing to pay, thanks to low interest rates on home improvement loans, said Brian Reid, publisher of Swimmingpools101.com, an informational Web site. 
 Judging from the site's message board and visitor feedback, he said, ''We've noticed a real trend in luxury upgrades of homes,'' with pools built as much for enjoyment as to increase property value. 
 Purely as an investment, installing a pool is not as good as, say, renovating a kitchen. A home's resale value generally increases by only 35 percent to 50 percent of a pool's cost, according to the American Society of Appraisers, a trade group in Herndon, Va., while a homeowner should recoup 65 percent to 85 percent of the cost of a new kitchen. 
 Part of the cost of building a pool may be tax-deductible if a doctor recommends swimming or any other form of water exercise as therapy for a medical condition like arthritis. So perhaps the chief motivation for building a lap pool is for its fitness benefits. ''Lap pools are really big now that the baby boomers are getting older and looking for ways to exercise without stressing their joints,'' said Tom Griffiths, an aquatic safety consultant and author of ''The Swimming Pool,'' a consumer guide to designing and building a pool.
 And the pool need not be outdoors. Ben D. Hill, a real estate developer in Grand Junction, Colo., had a swim-in-place lap pool installed in his home last year. The 7-by-15-foot pool, in a sunroom next to his bedroom, has powerful jets that keep Mr. Hill stationary while he strokes against the continuous current.
 ''I'm a runner, but I was beginning to get those aches and pains that come with age,'' said Mr. Hill, 52. Since installing his pool, he said, he swims four days a week, and ''my knees are in much better shape.''
 Mr. Hill's pool is made of molded fiberglass, which was delivered like a big tub on the back of a flatbed truck for his contractor to slip into the floor. Fiberglass is also used for outdoor above- and below-ground pools, but homeowners are limited to the preformed shapes and sizes available. 
 CONCRETE and vinyl-lined pools, which are generally in-ground, can be made to fit any area and design. Concrete pools are supported by a skeleton of rebar and are usually surfaced with plaster. A vinyl-lined pool has a vinyl surface covering a sand base and walls made out of steel, fiberglass, aluminum or pressure-treated wood. 
 Above-ground fiberglass pools are obviously less expensive, because there is no excavation involved. But since the cost of an in-ground pool has more to do with the digging and engineering required than the materials used, Brian Van Bower, a pool designer and owner of Aquatic Consultants Inc. in Miami, said that ''people should just choose the vessel material that has the look they want and the feel they prefer under their feet.'' 
 What drives up the price of a pool, Mr. Van Bower and other pool experts said, are the choices among types of filters, heaters, lighting, pumps and border tiles, not to mention the cost of the surrounding deck, patio and landscaping. On the high end would be a pool like Dale Doorly's, which he had built in 2002 in his backyard in San Diego. A financial consultant with Smith Barney, Mr. Doorly said he wanted not only a pool for exercise but a ''thing of beauty.'' So his 23-by-40-foot pool has an artful ''infinity'' edge, with the water on one side spilling into an invisible trough to create the illusion that there is no retaining wall. 
 There is also a ''sheer descent'' waterfall -- meaning it falls in a smooth sheet -- and sprinklers that telescope up from the bottom. A fiber-optic lighting system makes the pool seem to glow at night, and a solar-powered heating system keeps it comfortable year-round. Moreover, the pool is virtually maintenance-free, thanks to a top-of-the-line ozone filtration system and automatic chlorinator. 
 Mr. Doorly said the total cost, which he would not disclose, was three times as much as ''your basic pump-and-filter pool.'' But he added that the upfront cost would save him money over time. The pool's heating, lighting and sanitary systems are so efficient that he spends next to nothing on chemicals, electricity and general upkeep. ''Pools are a pay-me-now, pay-me-later kind of thing,'' he said. Maintenance costs vary widely, but chemicals and cleaning supplies alone can run $300 to $500 a year. 
 Because there are so many options, it is important to find a pool builder who is knowledgeable as well as independent.
 ''YOU probably don't want someone who is affiliated with any one supplier or who has any exclusive distribution deals, because you're not going to find out about all your options,'' said Mr. Reid at Swimmingpools101.com. Before signing on with anyone, pool owners and designers advise inspecting at least three pools the company has built. They also suggest requesting the names of recent customers as well as those from several years ago to see how pools have held up over time. 
 And, make sure that the warranty covers not only the pool but also all the ancillary systems like filtration, plumbing, heating and lighting. 
 Also, Mrs. Miller in Houston said, be prepared for a ''huge mess'' during construction. Wincing at the memory of her smashed sidewalk, trampled shrubs and the mud pit that almost swallowed the backhoe, she said, ''It looked like a bomb went off while they were building it, but the payoff was this totally great pool. I love my pool.''

QUICK READ
If you're thinking of installing a pool -- whether for cooling off or for stress-free exercise -- consider these points:

COST
A basic pool costs $20,000 to $50,000. Extras like underwater speakers, waterfalls, computerized filters, solar heating and fiber-optic lighting can increase the price tenfold. Pools are tax-deductible if they help a medical condition.

BENEFITS
Lap pools can fit in a small space. With endless-current jets, pools can be as small as 7 by 10 feet. They can increase a home's value by 35 to 50 percent of their cost, and swimming is excellent exercise.

DRAWBACKS
If not equipped with automatic filtering and chlorination systems, pools require weekly cleaning and chemical treatments. Filters must be changed every four to six months. Pools can raise property taxes and insurance rates.

TYPES
Concrete, vinyl-lined and fiberglass are the most common choices. There is often little difference in cost if the pool is installed below ground, so pool material is more a matter of personal preference.

BUILDERS
Find a contractor who is not affiliated with a particular manufacturer. Ask to see pools the contractor has built and talk with the homeowners. And make sure warranties cover not just the pool but also any lighting or heating systems.

SAFETY
The Consumer Product Safety Commission's Web site (www.cpsc.gov) explains measures you can take to prevent injuries and reduce potential liability.

HEADLINE: Yesterday's Earnings Don't Move Stocks. Tomorrow's Do.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
ON July 27, the Jones Apparel Group announced earnings for the second quarter that were better than expected. Revenue also came in ahead of forecasts. 
 You might have thought that the company's shares would rise on this news, but you would have been wrong.
 In fact, Jones's stock dropped 2.1 percent that day and was down 5.3 percent Friday from its pre-earnings announcement price. 
 Why did the stock drop? A major reason is that along with its report on past earnings, the company gave guidance to investors on its earnings outlook for the third quarter. It was much gloomier than anticipated, as much as 17 cents a share below Wall Street expectations.
 The decline of the company's stock, despite strong second-quarter earnings, shows the importance that the market places on company guidance -- Wall Street jargon for corporate predictions about future earnings. 
 Missing current earnings forecasts is often a problem for a company's stock, as is a shortfall on current revenue. Much of the talk and analysis during each quarterly earnings reporting season is focused on how many companies have missed, met or beaten expectations for that quarter and by how much.
 But company guidance, while much less concrete than earnings, is a very influential factor that is being looked at more closely now as analysts seek to figure out why strong earnings -- they are expected to rise 25 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the second quarter -- are not pushing stocks higher.
 A look at the performance of companies that have reported their earnings and given guidance shows that trimming the future earnings outlook -- or just giving guidance below Wall Street forecasts for the quarters ahead -- can offset what was otherwise a strong earnings announcement. Of course, other factors, like $44 crude oil, and worries about an economic slowdown, have dragged the market down recently, including last week. 
 For investors, though, the market response to company guidance could provide some short-term opportunities for those who like to trade. 
 Of the 33 companies from the S.&P. 500 and the Nasdaq 100 whose guidance was lower than market expectations when announcing second-quarter profits, shares of 27, or 82 percent, declined on the first trading opportunity after the news, based on an analysis of data collected by Birinyi Associates, a research and money management firm in Westport, Conn. The stock of 23 was still down through Wednesday. 
 The Jones Apparel Group, whose brands include Jones New York, Gloria Vanderbilt and Nine West, was among them. Avon Products and Visteon, the auto-parts manufacturer, also beat earnings and revenue expectations but gave guidance that was below Wall Street consensus forecasts. Avon fell 1.7 percent the day of the announcement, while Visteon dropped 3 percent. Through Friday, Avon was down 2.6 percent and Visteon 13.1 percent.
 The performance of companies that raised their guidance -- saying, in effect, that Wall Street was underestimating their earnings for coming quarters -- shows a similar, but reverse, relationship. Of the 45 companies that issued such guidance, shares of 31, or 69 percent, rose on the first trading day after the news release; 33, or 73 percent, were up through Wednesday. Among these were Apple Computer and Eastman Kodak, which jumped 11.3 percent and 9.1 percent, respectively, in the first day of trading after the news. As of Friday, Apple was still up 0.7 percent, while Kodak was up 8.1 percent.
 For investors, company guidance could inform short-term buying or selling decisions. For example, companies that lowball their guidance to help them exceed future earnings expectations may add to investor anxiety but also often make their stock briefly cheaper.
 Ford and Microsoft are in this category, according to some analysts. Ford beat second-quarter forecasts for earnings and revenue and also raised its guidance for 2004. But even that increase, to a range of $1.80 to $1.90 a share, left the company 4 cents to 14 cents below Wall Street forecasts. Ford's stock dropped 2.5 percent on the day of the announcement and was, by Friday, 6.1 percent below the pre-earnings announcement level.
 MICROSOFT earnings for the second quarter were in line with expectations, while revenue was higher. But the company's very conservative forecast for growth in the next 12 months helped send the stock down 3.3 percent on the first day after the announcement. On Friday, Microsoft was 6.4 percent below the pre-earnings announcement level. There is a good chance that the market is underestimating Microsoft's earnings potential, though. Microsoft was also guiding the market down when it reported second-quarter earnings in 1999. The stock responded by dropping 16.9 percent to $40.88 in the four weeks after the July announcement. It finished the year at $58.38. 
 The data also shows that leaving a company's guidance unchanged can hurt a stock's performance, just as it often is not good enough for a company only to match its earnings expectations. Of the 309 companies through Wednesday that didn't change their guidance, 49 percent fell on the trading day after the announcement.
 But be warned. Of the 33 companies that beat earnings and revenue expectations and raised their guidance, five still fell significantly. These were Broadcom, Electronic Arts, Novellus Systems, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide. Guidance can be misleading.

SECTION: Section 8A; Column 1; Sports Desk; ATHENS: SUMMER 2004 OLYMPICS -- JASON L. READ/U.S.A. ROWING; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 1396 words

HEADLINE: Motivation From 9/11 Pulls the Oars

BYLINE: By JULIET MACUR

 BODY:
For weeks, the raw images inside Jason Read's mind had disappeared.
 The five days he had spent at ground zero after the towers fell -- wiggling into smoldering holes to search for survivors, picking through rubble, watching last rites given to firefighters younger than himself -- all gone.
 ''My brain was probably doing it to protect me,'' he said. ''That was good because no one is strong enough to process everything that happened down there. You needed time to heal first.'' 
 For Read, a rower on the United States national team and volunteer chief of the Amwell Valley Rescue Squad in Ringoes, N.J., the healing came in quiet places. In his room, with the lights low. At a church, head bowed. On the water, pulling on his oar.
 And now, though the painful memories of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center will never be gone, Read has transformed them into a positive force: motivation. 
 The 26-year-old will row in the sport's glamour event, the men's eight, at this summer's Olympics. Although he has been on the senior national team three times before, he said this time would be different. He wants to help the United States eight win its first Olympic gold medal in 40 years -- not for himself, but for America, for the people who lost their lives or loved ones on Sept. 11, 2001.
 ''All of my emotions from that time have been building up inside of me for so long,'' Read said, holding back tears. ''They are fuel for me, and I'm going to harness them and win.
 ''I envision it every day,'' he added. ''I'll be standing there under the American flag, singing the national anthem. Well, I'll sing, I guess, if I can. I'll be so broken up. I'll be lucky to talk at that point.''
 Read, whom his teammates and coaches call ''J.R.'' or ''Chief Read,'' is 6 feet -1 inch and 180 pounds, with brown unruly hair and tanned skin. But what stands out most is his quirky personality, a combination of sensitive and cocky, serious and goofy. 
 One instant, Read is the man who, at 21, became the youngest volunteer fire chief in New Jersey. He is soulful, mulling over thoughts before verbalizing them in what may be poetry. 
 The next, he is giddy, showing off photos of his most recent crush, a Princeton woman he met while training at the university's boathouse. During rowing practices, to cut the tension, he always finds something upbeat to say. ''I know how to inject needed levity into any situation,'' Read said, all scholarly. 
 When he was 12, his two brothers, both older, simply thought he was obnoxious. Blame it on a friend's police and fire scanner, which he listened to daily.
 Soon, Read had a scanner of his own and listened to it with such passion that his brothers schemed to destroy it. ''He drove them crazy with all those little beeping sounds,'' said Read's mother, Joan. ''It was like when he was 4, he was obsessed with naming all the state capitals, all day long. He puts his mind to something and stays there.''
 Read was 14 when he joined the Hopewell Fire Department in New Jersey as a junior volunteer. At 16, he became an emergency medical technician. At 17, during summers, he signed onto the Atlantic City Beach Patrol.
 When he was 13, just before his career in rescue began, Read joined his school's crew team, first as a coxswain, the small guy who sits in the stern of the boat, steering and shouting commands. As a freshman at The Hun School of Princeton, he switched to rowing, just a scrawny kid, at 5-1, 115 pounds, with big hopes. That season at the Princeton University boathouse, where his school trained, he met Mike Teti, then a national team rower, now the Olympic team coach. 
 Read walked up to Teti, smiling wide, silver braces gleaming, and said, ''I'm going to row with you in the Olympics one day.'' Teti remembers looking at the boy slim and light as a Popsicle stick and saying, ''Sure, kid, sure.''
 Eventually, Read grew another 12 inches, but was still small for heavyweight rowing, in which there is no maximum size. He has size 14 feet, but is the shortest and lightest man in the United States' men's eight. The other rowers are at least 6-3 and 200 pounds. The biggest one is 6-7, 215.
 Teti said Read's confidence makes up for his size. ''I don't even think J.R. has to train,'' he said. ''His will is just that powerful. Usually, rowing is 30 percent physical, 30 percent technical and 30 percent psychological, but with Jason, it's 10 percent physical, 5 percent technical, and 85 percent that he really just believes that he is the man.''
 At home in New Jersey, Read is the man, in a different way. He lives with his mother in a perfectly appointed house, on a farm of rolling hills where his family used to stable horses and hounds for fox hunting. Between rowing practices at Princeton, 20 minutes away, he is still chief of his rescue squad, active in administrative and hands-on duties.
 When not trying to raise $100,000 for a new squad station, he tends to car accidents, fires and construction-site mishaps, like a recent one in which a worker broke his leg and several ribs, and could not breathe.
 ''If my teammates and coach knew I was going into a burning building or doing these dangerous things, they'd kill me,'' he said. ''So I just tell them I took a nap.''
 And napping is what Read was doing the morning of Sept. 11, before he woke up to the sound of his mother crying. 
 He was at home, just back from the World Rowing Championships in Lucerne, Switzerland, depressed because the team had finished fourth. Returning to regular life, he was commuting to Temple University in Philadelphia, where he was a senior economics major on a rowing scholarship.
 But on Sept. 11, he was neither student nor athlete; he was a rescue worker. He grabbed his lifesaving gear and was off. That night at Liberty State Park, at 23 years old, he was the volunteer communications officer, in charge of mobilizing about 500 doctors, nurses, E.M.T.'s and other emergency workers.
 In the silence of an eerie evening, even after no survivors came ashore from Manhattan, he kept going. He took a ferry to ground zero to help set up one of the site's major treatment areas. 
 Walking through the World Financial Center, he learned what he would be dealing with. ''It's where I found a leg,'' he said. 
 ''For most people, 9/11 was different because they had to digest hundreds, maybe thousands of images from that day,'' he said. ''But for the people who were there, we have to somehow reflect and face a profound experience. Our minds were inundated with hundreds of thousands of images. Do you know what kind of introspection that causes? I thought, 'Why am I still rowing? I should be enlisting.'''
 The images are burned into Read's head now: an American flag waving above the wreckage that was the World Trade Center, many American flags draped over the bodies of the dead firefighters pulled from the twisted, smoldering metal. He had nightmares for months after that search-and-rescue mission.
 That fall, he took the semester off from Temple, worrying his mother because he did not talk much anymore.
 ''He backed away from a lot of family and friends,'' Joan Read said. ''And he threw himself into rowing.''
 With Read in the boat, pulling hard and always keeping what he calls the ''morale-o-meter'' up with his encouraging words, the United States eight won a bronze medal at the worlds that year. Last year, it was silver. This June, Read was in the United States four that shocked the favored Canadians and British by winning a World Cup race in Lucerne. This year, Teti said, is Read's best season yet.
 Read said a newfound spirituality has played a part in that. He was baptized Lutheran, rarely going to church before Sept. 11. But on Easter 2002, he reaffirmed his faith in God and was confirmed in the Catholic Church, moved by the support he was given after Sept. 11 by Catholic friends and the Rev. Thomas Mullelly, the chaplain for the national rowing team and for Princeton. 
 On his confirmation day, Read received a small card from his sponsor, Hank Teti, Mike Teti's father. On it is his name, the word ''Healer'' and a Bible verse.
 Read choked up when he read the card, gently touching the edges as he whispered: ''I've been given strength by someone -- that's a capital Someone -- to help people who are in the most compromising positions. I don't know why. I don't know why I've been blessed that way.''

HEADLINE: Africans Find a Refuge In Cast-Off 'Big Boxes'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG 

 BODY:
FROM her place behind the barred window of the Nonto Tuck Shop in Soweto, Constance Jwara sells lollipops and soda, salt and sugar and plates of meat and pap, an African staple made of boiled cornmeal. To her left is a dry cleaner's. To her right, an older woman sells fruit, vegetables and a sampling of native condiments. 
 As suburban strip malls go, it's not unlike that found in many American towns. With one exception: it consists entirely of shipping containers. 
 Western retail architecture is defined by golden arches and big-box merchandisers. In much of poorer Africa -- in much of the developing world -- ''big box'' means a rusting container of corrugated steel, usually 20 feet long, culled from giant cargo ships for use as a restaurant, a beauty salon, or, as the accompanying photographs suggest, you name it. 
 Condemning this container sprawl as the ultimate expression of the West's disposable society would be easy. The container is a spectacularly successful American invention, and the homely ones that litter the African landscape are mostly the leavings of big Western shippers. 
 But it isn't that simple. Many Africans who have converted the containers -- into schools, community centers and even homes -- might disagree. They are the grown-up equivalents of the empty refrigerator box that children play in. Ugly or not, containers can become anything one wants -- and cheaply. 
 Which is why, in a region where all too many people live under trash-bag roofs, they are ubiquitous. 
 Shipping containers did not exist until 1956, when a North Carolina trucking tycoon named Malcolm McLean loaded 58 of them onto a converted oil tanker in a bid to automate the loading and unloading of cargo, which was then done mostly by hand. Today 90 percent of the world's cargo moves in containers-- and the equivalent of 1.4 million 20-foot containers move in and out of South Africa alone each year. 
 Thomas Greh, a German filmmaker who has made a documentary about the container industry, says the ebb and flow of world trade is partly responsible for the container gluts in developing regions. 
 In essence, he says, the First World ships millions of containers of finished goods to Africa, but Africa has far fewer full containers to ship back. 
 ''Sometimes, the costs are just too high to bring an empty container back to the next harbor,'' he said in a telephone interview, ''and the shipping company sells the container instead.''
 That may happen, other experts say, particularly when the containers are far inland and must be trucked to a port. But it is more common for firms to simply sell the containers when their seaworthy lives end, usually after 5 to 10 years. 
 According to Safmarine, a Cape Town shipping firm, a container that cost $2,000 new will fetch as much as $700 as surplus. Some companies donate old containers to schools and charities; Safmarine, for example, has given away 7,000 since 1991. 
 The container housing Nonto Tuck Shop (a tuck shop is akin to a convenience store) was in fact given to Soweto's Nanto primary school in the mid-1990's by local Coca-Cola officials. The school leases it to an operator for 450 rand a month, about $70, and uses the proceeds to support school activities. 
 The operator, in turn, pays Ms. Jwara 450 rand a month. She uses that money to support her family -- three children, the child of a sick brother and an unemployed husband. 
 Ms. Jwara was unemployed before landing the job in May. She has a fourth-grade education. ''I like this job,'' she says, ''because it's the only one that I can do.''
 In parts of Africa right now, that is reason enough. Sometimes, it seems, even a homely steel rectangle can twist itself into a benevolent circle.

HEADLINE: Indochina War Refugees Find Homes at Last, in U.S.

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: SARABURI, Thailand 

 BODY:
It is a scene from what seems the distant past: 15,000 refugees from the American war in Indochina clustered in a guarded camp, preparing at last to head for asylum in the United States.
 Monsoon rains make rivers of their muddy paths and blanket their tin-roofed huts with white noise as they sit in little classrooms for crash courses on becoming Americans.
 The first small groups began departing in June, but the camp will not be empty for months. 
 Like more than three million refugees who came before them, the people here -- or their parents -- fled their country after the war ended in 1975. But unlike almost all the rest, they have remained in stateless limbo, long after refugee programs closed around Asia. 
 They are Hmong tribespeople from the mountains of Laos, an ethnic group that was recruited wholesale by the Central Intelligence Agency to fight in its ''secret war'' in that tiny country neighboring Vietnam. When the Communist Pathet Lao overthrew the United States-backed government in 1975, a large part of the Hmong population fled, fearing reprisals. 
 Some people are calling the current resettlement the end of one of the great refugee movements in history, the last significant migration from the era that included Vietnamese boat people and starving Cambodian refugees.
 ''It's reasonable to assume that this is the last big group,'' said W. Courtland Robinson, author of a book about Indochina refugees called ''Terms of Refuge.'' Veterans of the war and other supporters of the Hmong say the United States owes a debt to these people it left behind when the war ended. Since then, 127,000 have been resettled in the United States, where their population has swelled.
 The people here refused to go with them, hoping some day to cross the Mekong River back to Laos. When the camps that held them closed in the early 1990's, they found a home in the fields around a Buddhist temple here called Wat Tham Krabok, about 50 miles north of Bangkok. 
 Then, late last year, the United States agreed to a longstanding request by the Thai government to take them all, filling an annual refugee quota after arrivals dropped sharply following the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Most of the people at the temple are ready to go. This is not the same population that refused asylum a decade ago. Three out of four people here were born in Thailand.
 These are refugees not from a war but from a refugee camp.
 ''We ask them, 'Where are you from?' '' said KaYing Yang, 36, a Hmong-American social worker who runs a cultural orientation program here. ''They have no idea where they are from in Laos. They've never been to Laos.'' 
 Refugee support groups in the United States say tens of thousands more Hmong who could have a claim on asylum are scattered around Thailand. But nobody is being added to the current list, and the United States is unlikely to take many more. Thailand says it will close the camp, and the future remains uncertain for a small number of mostly older people here who say they will not go. A number of others who do wish to go were missed by a census last year that has become the official, inflexible departure list.
 Refugee flows never have a clean end, Mr. Robinson said. It is not a surprise to find little pools left behind like Wat Tham Krabok. There are always more claimants for asylum and more families reaching back to take their relatives.
 ''So nobody should be scratching their heads and saying, 'How can this be, 30 years after the conflict?'''
 The first waves of Hmong were among the least prepared refugees ever accepted by the United States, mostly illiterate soldiers and farmers who had had little contact with modern life.
 They have clustered mostly in Minnesota, Wisconsin and California, and these established communities will help cushion the arrival of the newcomers. Local governments and aid groups have mobilized to help.
 By now, the refugees here are familiar with televisions, cellphones and video cameras, which have replaced the stitched story cloths on which the Hmong had traditionally recorded their lives.
 But in the cultural orientation classes they attend, they are still fascinated by a modern kitchen, and they are awed by flush toilets.
 ''They are all afraid of the toilet,'' Ms. Yang said. ''The old people, 'Wow!' they push the lever, 'Where did the water come from?'''
 Ms. Yang is one of five Hmong-Americans who came here to help prepare the refugees for a new life. Their presence shows the different lives of those who accepted resettlement and those who stayed behind.
 ''We give them a small review of the United States,'' Ms. Yang said, ''about Native Americans, Christopher Columbus, the colors of the flag, the seasons, the snow -- 'Do you know what snow looks like?' ''
 The students are drilled in American values, and if they forget any they can check key words, tacked to the wall on slips of colored paper: independence, self-reliance, equality, privacy, punctuality, time, individualism, rights, flag, stars, stripes.
 The Hmong are told that in the United States polygamy is forbidden and that beating one's children is considered a crime. They are told that they need hunting licenses if they are going to track animals in the woods. The first wave of Hmong refugees in the United States was known for its insularity and dependence on welfare, clustering in tight-knit groups. They continue to develop slowly, economically and socially. Ms. Yang spans the generations. A refugee who was born in Laos, she passed through a camp in Thailand, moved with her parents to the United States and earned a college degree.
 ''Maybe it's just me and my group of friends, but I see a lot of success,'' she said. Her Hmong background, though, has left her feeling lost, she said. This is a culture that was torn apart during the war, when most men became soldiers, huge numbers died and much of the population was displaced.
 When the war ended, hundreds of thousands of Hmong and lowland Lao people fled into Thailand, where they were sheltered in vast camps close to the border.
 ''We are a stateless people,'' Ms. Yang said. ''What is our identity? What does that mean? Many here are traumatized. The whole community is having an identity crisis. They don't know who they are.''
 She asks herself the same questions.
 ''My whole life, I've wanted to work in a refugee camp,'' she said. ''How did I get here? Who am I?''
 For lack of anything else, Wat Tham Krabok is the only home the people here have. Their lives are familiar and manageable and their friends are close at hand, all of them speaking Hmong.
 Though most people are eager to become Americans, some of the older refugees say they fear the strangeness and isolation they will find in a foreign land where people are independent, self-reliant and punctual.
 Deep inside the camp is a narrow path where tinkers and blacksmiths work in the snug shelter of roofs and lean-tos above their heads.
 The path is filled with the sounds of hammers and saws and the smell of sweet smoke from small forges.
 The men sit together filing, grinding and hammering, talking quietly with one another. It is a picture of contentment and fellowship that they may never experience again.

HEADLINE: The S.E.C.'s Infrequent Filer Plan

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
TARO PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES is an Israeli company with sales of $316 million and a formerly highflying stock that trades on the Nasdaq. The company is also Exhibit A for why securities regulators absolutely must increase the financial filing requirements of foreign corporations if they want to protect investors from the kind of bloodbath that Taro shareholders recently endured.
 For a foreign company, Taro is mighty domestic. Ninety percent of its sales are generated in the United States while 5 percent come from Canada. More than a quarter of the company's employees work in the United States. 
 But because it is incorporated in Israel, it is a so-called foreign filer under Securities and Exchange Commission rules. That means it is required to file pretty much one thing: an annual financial report, known as a 20F. Quarterly filings are optional, leaving investors mostly in the dark during the course of the year.
 And while the S.E.C. has been requiring domestic companies to speed up the filing of their annual reports -- now they must come in 75 days after the year concludes versus 90 days under previous rules -- foreign filers still have altogether too much time to file. Taro filed its annual report for the year that ended in December 2003 on June 29, 2004. 
 As it happened, that filing, reporting rosy rates of growth, came smack in the middle of a severe downturn in Taro's business. Investors reading the annual report got a different impression: it said 2003 sales increased 49 percent while profits rose 37 percent. 
 Two months before filing its annual report, the company issued a press release announcing that first-quarter net income had fallen 21 percent. And on July 29, it said in another press release that its second-quarter sales had dropped 35 percent from the same period in 2003 and that its profits were less than half the levels seen a year earlier. 
 Taro also said that its largest customers were cutting purchases of its products significantly. But neither of these press releases, nor press releases for earlier quarters, included cash flow statements for the company or financial footnotes, both of which are typically found in quarterly S.E.C. filings by domestic companies. 
 Such detailed information could have helped investors see a pothole ahead. They were, after all, accustomed to the company's hot-rod stock: shares that had traded for less than $10 during most of 2000 had hit a high of around $72 last December, giving the company a market value of $2.14 billion. 
 Before the April disappointment, Taro's stock was at $62. It fell 27 percent the following day. On the second-quarter news, the shares dropped 20 percent more. Since April, $1.2 billion in market value has evaporated. The shares changed hands at $21.18 at the end of the day Friday, down 67 percent this year. 
 Analysts at Glass, Lewis & Company, an independent research and institutional advisory firm in San Francisco, were less surprised by the Taro debacle than most investors. On April 5, the firm had issued an alert to its clients, pointing out, among other things, weakness in operating cash flows at the company and a slow rate of turnover in inventories. It advised its clients to be wary of Taro stock, noting that it traded at a premium to comparable companies that had much stronger cash flows. The shares were at $59.43 when the report was published.
 Because Taro's quarterly press releases do not include cash flow details, the professionals at Glass, Lewis had a tough time piecing together a picture of the company. For the average investor, such a task would have been nigh impossible. 
 However, piece Glass, Lewis did, with data gleaned from Taro's press releases. The result was a company that appeared to be in a financial crisis, said Greg Taxin, the chief executive of Glass, Lewis. 
 ''There is no economic or political justification for allowing foreign companies to access efficient U.S. capital markets with only scant and occasional disclosure about their businesses,'' said Mr. Taxin. ''We rely on orderly and comprehensive disclosure to keep our markets efficient and protect investors. With some of these foreign filers, it is the Wild West -- they disclose what they want, when they want.''
 And this disclosure gap is likely to become more of a problem for investors as they turn increasingly to foreign stocks as an alternative to swooning domestic shares. The United States dollar's slide has also propelled more investors into stocks of overseas companies. 
 Daniel Saks, Taro's spokesman, said: ''We have always complied, on a timely basis, with all disclosure requirements applicable to us under U.S. law. We reported on our first and second quarters of this year on April 29, 2004, and July 29, 2004, in each case more than two weeks before U.S. companies were required to report on their comparable quarters.'' 
 Asked if the company was considering increasing its disclosure beyond what the S.E.C. requires, Mr. Saks said: ''We will change our disclosure practices in response to any change in applicable requirements.''
 But Mr. Taxin said: ''More than a billion dollars has been lost suddenly by investors in Taro, and I think it fair for them to ask: When did the company know about these problems and why didn't it warn investors clearly and earlier?''
 Unfortunately, the answer may be, because it didn't have to.

HEADLINE: Camp, Shmamp. I'd Rather Play With the Fireflies.

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS; Kevin Cahillane and Jane Gordon contributed reporting for this article.

 BODY:
THERE was a time, at least in the misty land of memory, when a clear line of demarcation existed between the last day of school and the first day of summer vacation. Walking out of the schoolhouse door, clutching the raggedy contents of his or her desk, a child felt that moment of liberation from school pressures -- both social and academic -- as keenly as a convict released from jail.
 Those were the days, as myth would have it, when mothers were more available, streets were safe enough for children to roam and the suburbs were still new, planted with modest houses and spindly trees. Those were the days when children did not have to do but could just be.
 Summer was the time for sleeping late, digging in the dirt, roaming the neighborhood on a bike, playing kick the can and war. 
 But then the line between the end of school and the beginning of summer began to grow fuzzier. Summer turned into a continuation of the rest of the year, a season of expensive sleep-away camps, sweaty sports camps and globe-trotting adventures. Only the uncool, the disorganized and families with no other options kept their children at home, dependent on their own wit and imagination to keep busy.
 Today change is in the air once again. Some people in the suburbs say they see a countertrend developing -- a movement back toward the unabashedly ordinary, low-pressure summers that parents remember from their own childhoods: summers of catching fireflies, getting to know cousins and visiting grandparents. 
 In Westchester, a group of boys meet at the schoolyard most afternoons to play a lazy game of stickball. In Connecticut, a mother who gave up her job as a litigator to spend more time with her children has found that her children were burned out by the effort to make summer stimulating instead of relaxing, and would rather just stay home.
 On Long Island, the Hempstead town supervisor has seen a rise in the number of children enrolling in free or low-cost summer recreation programs. And in New Jersey, a family is rediscovering the public library. To some degree, parents say, they are rebelling against the high cost of summer camps. But a more subtle cultural change may be in the air, a conviction that the competition to turn summer into an extension of the school year, an endless race to get into Harvard, has gotten out of hand. People are exhausted by the effort to find a summer activity that will look good on a college application. And they are no longer convinced that getting into the right summer camp is important to their children's future.
 In Ryan Kahn's case, staying home was a choice. At 14, he was old enough to make his own decision. He had tried sleep-away camp in past years and liked it well enough. But he decided that this year he wanted a break.
 Ryan goes to a daily tennis camp in his hometown, New Rochelle. But when camp is over, at 4 p.m., he spends most afternoons playing stickball with his friends at George M. Davis Jr. Elementary School. They don't even have to call one another in advance; they just know to show up. Many evenings, they get together for a game of poker.
 The chemistry between Ryan and his friends may have something to do with their decision to spend the summer hanging out together. 
 ''This is a special group of kids,'' said Caryn Englander, mother of Sam, one of Ryan's friends. ''They're kind to each other. They don't have cliques.''
 After stickball, Ryan has dinner, then watches the news or a baseball game. He runs a small business taking orders for a printing company on commission. He reads from his school's summer reading list. (Right now he is in the middle of ''The Body of Christopher Creed'' by Carol Plum-Ucci.) 
 His mother, Pam, is usually at home during the day, and he likes the feeling of being in the house with her, not necessarily interacting very much, but keeping each other company.
 But he also enjoys a certain amount of solitude. ''I just like to have time to myself, just thinking,'' he said.
 Kathy Coleman, who lives in Scarsdale, describes herself as ''anti-sleep-away camp.'' Her children are on the town swim team, but only for part of the summer. Ms. Coleman sells a line of children's clothing from her home, and can scale back her work during the summer to spend more time with her children, Emma, 5, and Julia, 9.
 THEIR summer so far has consisted of going to the town pool, the library or the beach, and doing chores around the house, like painting the bathroom apple green.
 Her older daughter reads a lot, and has plowed through ''How I Survived Being a Girl'' by Wendelin Van Draanen, the fourth volume of ''Harry Potter'' and several other books.
 ''I didn't go to nursery school,'' Ms. Coleman said. ''I didn't go to summer school, and I live a decent life now. My kids have had so much more than I had growing up. I guess I just don't want to wreck it by making them do something every minute of the day.'' 
 Judy Rintoul, a former litigator who is raising two children, Max, 10, and Emily, 12, in the central Connecticut town of Portland, shared some of Ms. Coleman's distaste for overscheduling.
 ''We did do a lot of the sort of busy suburban summer life at one time,'' she said. ''The stress of running around and the competitiveness of being in those programs was just not what we were looking for, and we found that being more selective about what we took them to in the summer ended up being more fun and more relaxing. We just felt that it built our family in new ways. It gives us more time to do things with each other, to learn about each other, to learn about ourselves.''
 The family's retreat into summer domesticity began four years ago with Ms. Rintoul's retirement from her job as an employment litigator.
 During a trial, she found, she might work 15-hour days and have no control over when she could be at home. If she was, she would send her children to bed at 7 p.m., to get them out of the way so she could go back to work.
 Summer camps became a form of day care. ''I had to find something for them to do,'' she said, while she and her husband, David, also a lawyer, were at work. Her children went to art camps, sports camps and writing camps, and Ms. Rintoul had to begin the enrollment process for these camps as early as January.
 ''It was exhausting,'' she said. ''They had back-to-back camps -- some sleep-away, some day camps, some half-day camps. All the weeks and hours and drop-off and pick-up times had to match.''
 Three years ago, she started home-schooling her children. This year, it seemed a natural extension of home-schooling to keep them home for the summer. Her children, Ms. Rintoul said, have never been bored.
 They putter around the garden, read, play on the computer and have friends over. They go to the theater. The only structured activity is music lessons.
 ''This is the kind of time when kids think about who they are and how things work,'' she said, ''the time when they generate questions about the world.''
 Ms. Rintoul concedes that as her children reach high-school age, they might feel more pressured to find summer activities that they can show off on a college application. But she is not sure she will give in.
 ''It's not enough to be smart, it's not enough to be wealthy, it's not enough to be good-looking anymore,'' she said. ''Even those three things together are not enough anymore. All these people putting their children's noses to the grindstone are still not guaranteed that at the end of that they're going to have a successful, well-adjusted, happy adult. Maybe my children won't be the most competitive people, but they'll have things to offer, and they'll be unique things.''
 EMELINE and Dave Thornell keep their two children, Sydney, 9, and Aidan, 5, engaged over the summer simply by opening the front door. Their middle-class street in upper-crust Summit had 43 school-age children the last time someone thought to count. Mr. Thornell, a chemist for Northeast Laboratories in New York City, and Mrs. Thornell, a cardiac nurse at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, both work full time. 
 But they have stay-at-home children thanks to flexible work schedules and a reliable baby sitter. Mrs. Thornell, for one, is grateful for the comfort of neighbors.
 ''It's like it was when we were growing up,'' she said. ''Everyone on the block just goes outside and plays, and people talk to each other on the stoops. These days, everything has to be structured and there's this camp and that camp. I mean, did you ever go on a play date?''
 While this it-takes-a-village approach to bringing up children is nothing new, Mr. Thornell has added an atypical element to his children's summer itineraries: homework.
 Every afternoon, Sydney and Aidan retire to their rooms to read books, write letters, draw pictures and otherwise engage their creative and intellectual sensibilities during the otherwise dormant dog days of high summer.
 Sydney is passionate about dance, and Aidan has more natural athletic talent than you can shake a lacrosse stick at. But they don't miss camp; the highlight of the summer has been playing with the two new neighbor children next door.
 ''I wait at the window for them to come outside,'' Sydney said. When they do, the four go from house to house, running through sprinklers, watching ''Tom and Jerry'' videos and getting into their share of scrapes and bruises.
 In August, the Thornells take their show on the road to Mr. Thornell's parents' home in Massachusetts -- or, as Mrs. Thornell affectionately calls it, ''Camp Nana and Papa.''
 FLEXIBLE schedules seem typical among families whose children are home for the summer. That is the case with Mary Meyer, who lives in Glen Ridge, N.J., and keeps the payroll for her husband's security company. She does the books at night, or postpones some work until October, so she can stay home with Andrew, 12, and Carolyn, 10. The two have spent a week in theater camp, which is their passion, but otherwise they are improvising. Ms. Meyer admits that she keeps them home in part because camp is so expensive.
 But she keeps the atmosphere festive, even camplike. Her daughter has friends over for pajama parties. (They call them Cinderella sleepovers, because the children arrive in their pajamas but don't actually stay the night.) There are family game nights. The neighborhood children roam freely through backyards playing tag and having sword fights, and they catch fireflies at dusk.
 ''I think it's a great atmosphere for the kids,'' Ms. Meyer said.
 Bob and Leosinda Lebron of Jackson, N.J., have decided that summer camp is an unnecessary luxury. Their older boys, Alex, 15, and Kevin, 10, are able to stay home, and do whatever the day seems to dictate. 
 Mr. Lebron jostles the boys awake before leaving for his 75-minute journey up the parkway to his advertising job in Morristown. Mrs. Lebron drops off the baby, Sophie, 2, at a baby sitter's house in town before driving to her job as a programmer at Merrill Lynch in Hopewell. 
 The boys then crash for a few more hours on the couch, their circadian rhythms thrown out of whack by the horror movies they stay up late watching. 
 When they do rise, they engage in the most time-honored of summer traditions. ''We mostly watch TV and go outside,'' Kevin said. Outside amounts to collecting box turtles, playing hockey and throwing a stuffed teddy bear at a live hornets' nest. Occasionally, and with mixed results, their father will ask them to ''clean something.'' While the summer days pass languorously enough, afternoons and evenings are often devoted to shuttling back and forth to hockey practices and games all over South Jersey. Nobody seems to miss summer camp. 
 ''I spend enough money on hockey that I couldn't afford it even if I wanted to,'' Mr. Lebron said. ''Plus, I just think they're safer at home. Particularly when you have a retired police officer next door.''
 THE summer has also featured a two-week visit by Mrs. Lebron's sister and her family from Colombia, as well as field trips to the beach and even Yankee Stadium. 
 For other parents, like Ann Bonini, who lives in Canton, Conn., summer is a juggling act. Ms. Bonini works part time as a bookkeeper at Hartford Florist Supply, which is run by her husband, Richard. She often takes her children, Hannah, 5, Henry, 8, and Olivia, 10, to work with her, and they work, too.
 ''We fill out a time sheet,'' Henry said. ''And we clean walls and weed.''
 Henry admits that the summer days can be long, and he sometimes wishes he could go to camp. But his mother says they moved to their neighborhood of front porches, rolling lawns and smooth driveways so the children would have a place to play. Sending them away for the summer would defeat the purpose of living in such an idyllic setting. ''Camps are not necessary here,'' she said.
 And there are compensations to staying close to home. In less affluent families, relatives are likely to be relied on to take care of the children. Barbara Hicks, who is retired from working in a laundry and is rearing her granddaughters, Sasha, 15, and Shamira, 14, in Hartford, sees summer as a chance for the girls to spend time with their network of cousins and their older sister. 
 The bonds between the cousins, Ms. Hicks said, grow stronger with each passing summer.
 IN some places, government officials have tried to strip away the economic barriers that keep children home when they would rather be in camp.
 Kate Murray, the supervisor in the Long Island town of Hempstead, estimates that 2,500 children from 5 to 13 years old are taking part in free town recreational programs this summer, and that another 10,000 are taking swimming lessons. 
 ''Most of the time kids can ride their bike and get to a pool,'' she said. ''The accessibility is there. We offer a little bit of independence for kids growing up. They can spread their wings and be in a very safe environment.''
 And every time she visits a town pool, Ms. Murray says, she feels as if she were a child again, back in that misty land of memory, when she was free to be and not to do.

Sleeping In vs. Sleep-Away
 SHOULD parents send their children away for the summer? That depends on what those children have been doing for the rest of the year, said Ester S. Buchholz, a professor of applied psychology at New York University and the author of ''The Call of Solitude: Alonetime in a World of Attachment'' (Simon & Schuster, 1997).
 Some children do need a break, Dr. Buchholz said, because their lives have been too structured, too pressured. ''Our culture these days is very into not wasting a moment's time. We must teach our children everything under the sun starting from Day 1. 
 ''But if our thoughts are always monitored and programmed by others, then how do we build our own judgment, our own sense of who we are and our personal integrity?''
 But she pointed out that the overstructured life seems to be more of a problem for affluent children than for poor children. It is those who cannot afford to travel or to take music and art lessons who need summer camp the most, and who are least likely to get it.
 There is such a thing, Dr. Buchholz said, as too much stimulation. And constant activity can become a way of avoiding independent thinking. If the television or the camp counselor is always telling children what to do next, there is no need for them to be creative.
 ''If you look at the lives of the people who have been the most productive, if you look at the Einstein or the Mozart, they had a lot of time, a lot of space and quiet,'' she said. ''It's sort of funny that we want to emulate them, but we're actually not.'' ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON. 
E-mail: westarts@nytimes.com

 BODY:

Looking for a High Note
 The story of the Burla family of Hastings-on-Hudson has the makings of a movie: war, poverty, courage and devotion, as well as the extraordinary talent of a child. Nely and Marat Burla left their native Ukraine in 1990 in search of economic opportunity. 
 They moved to Israel, but bombing in their frontier town drove them underground. After four years they moved to Montreal and then Toronto, where Ms. Burla, a pianist and teacher, and her husband, a piano technician, found stability. It was in Toronto that Alice, now 7, was born, joining her brother, Konstantin, now 15. 
 Alice, who will enter the third grade at Hillside Elementary School in Hastings, showed unusual musical ability by the age of 2, and won a national Canadian piano competition when she was 5. Ms. Burla, who was Alice's teacher, thought the Juilliard School would give her daughter the best musical education. Alice auditioned and was accepted on a partial scholarship into the precollege division, an intensive program on Saturdays. The family moved to New York for Alice's sake, settling in Hastings because of its school system, ambience and proximity to Manhattan. But things have not gone well for the family. Mr. Burla has lost three jobs waiting for his work visa. Ms. Burla has not found a job, barely supporting the family with intermittent private teaching. ''It was a difficult winter,'' she said. ''We lived on donations.''
 Their plight caught the attention of a local newspaper, The Rivertowns Enterprise, based in Hastings. The music community gathered round the family, and as a result Alice, who has completed her first year at Juilliard, will give a concert on Aug. 18 at 6 p.m. at Frank and Camille's Fine Pianos in Manhattan, followed by a reception and the silent auction of a Yamaha Disklavier grand piano, a Yamaha professional upright and a Yamaha Clavinova digital piano. The suggested donation for the concert is $25. The proceeds will go to the Burlas. Information: (212)832-8289. 

Taking Cues Offstage
 Children aspiring to be professional Broadway singers and dancers will have the chance to meet two Broadway actresses at Youth Theater Interactions in Yonkers in the coming weeks. Youth Theater, an after-school performing arts organization, is presenting a series of free seminars in an effort to immerse young people in the performing life. On Thursday at 1 p.m. the speaker will be Susie Bigelow, an actress and singer who has appeared in ''Footloose,'' ''Oklahoma'' and ''South Pacific,'' as well as in soap operas. Michelle M. Robinson, an original cast member of the Broadway revival of ''Chicago,'' who also appeared in ''Jelly's Last Jam'' and ''Black and Blue,'' will speak about her career on Aug. 19 at 1 p.m. Information: (914)963-3040. 

Free With the Swing
 The season of free outdoor events continues with ''Summer Night's Swing'' on Wednesday at 6 p.m. at Renaissance Fountain Plaza, across from City Center in White Plains. Cappelli Enterprises is the host for the event, which will feature the Benson-Scott Big Band. Dancers from the Arthur Murray dance studio will conduct a group dance lesson, and Robert Royston, choreographer of the show ''Swing,'' will perform a swing dance. Free refreshments will be offered from 6 to 7 p.m. and free desserts from 9 to 10 p.m., by White Plains restaurants. 

Stories for a Summer Day
 The Mohegan Colony Association in Crompond will present its fourth annual festival of storytelling on Saturday from noon until 10 p.m. Stories for children will be told in an historic stone schoolhouse, adult stories under the Mohegan Colony Pavilion and a ghost story ''concert'' around the campfire at Mohegan Colony Beach (bring your own blankets, towels and chairs). 
 Judith Heineman, a storyteller, actress and performance artist, is coordinating the event, which includes Jonathan Kruk, Jack Maguire, Loren Niemi and a belly dancer, Gina Bergamini. Admission ranges from $15 to $10 for adults and $6 or $5 for children. A pot luck dinner can be bought for $5. Information: (914)528-5830. ROBERTA HERSHENSON

HEADLINE: Postcards From the Fringe

BYLINE: By JASON ZINOMAN

 BODY:
IS there such a thing as too many options? It can feel that way with the New York International Fringe Festival, that behemoth showcase that takes over the downtown theater scene every August. With performances beginning Friday and running through Aug. 29, the eighth annual fringe features 194 low-budget productions from nine countries and 30 American cities, being shown at 20 sites -- all of which make it the biggest theatrical crapshoot in North America. Pity the poor theatergoer trying to sort through the menu of eye-catching titles (''The Cosmic Calamities of Henry Noodle,'' a ''new sci-fi musical comedy adventure''), exercises in irony (''Jonestown: The Musical'') and proudly tasteless provocations (''Die, Die, Diana: A Musical''). 
 With adequate preparation, however, it is possible to locate the gems. So pore over the lineup, study every corner of the Web site, conduct extensive interviews with participants and do background research on all their former productions. Or just consider this abridged guide to the 10 shows that people will be (or should be) talking about. For more information from Present Company, the fringe producers: 212-279-4488 or www.fringenyc.org.

BELIEVE IN ME . . . A BIGFOOT MUSICAL
 It's the inevitable question: What show has the best chance to be the next ''Urinetown,'' the Broadway breakout that is the dream of many fringe artists? With a high-caliber artistic team and enthusiastic word of mouth, this musical, which has been praised by Mark Hollmann, the composer of ''Urinetown,'' on its Web site (www.big footmusical. com), might have the best shot. The well-regarded songwriter Michael Holland, half of the chic cabaret duo Gashole, composed the music and lyrics; Adrien Royce wrote the book, based on a stage play, about a documentary filmmaker who becomes obsessed with finding Bigfoot. Schaeberle Studio Theater at Pace University: Saturday at 7:45 p.m.; Aug. 17 at 3 p.m.; Aug. 19 at 5 p.m.; Aug. 26 at 8 p.m.; Aug. 27 at 4:45 p.m. 

ARMLESS
 Kyle Jarrow, New York's hipster playwright du jour, has a strange sense of humor. Earlier this year, he helped write ''A Very Merry Unauthorized Children's Scientology Pageant,'' a deadpan musical biography of L. Ron Hubbard in which child actors spouted the teachings of Scientology. The offbeat show turned into an unlikely hit. Now Mr. Jarrow, who moonlights in a Devo-like band called the Fabulous Entourage, has written a grotesque comedy about a man (played by Sam Turich, above) who has unusual body issues: he desperately wants to cut off his arms. Sound weird? ''Look, it's his body: why can't he do whatever he wants with it? I'm conflicted about it,'' Mr. Jarrow says. ''It also strikes me as really funny.'' Plaza Cafe at Pace University: next Sunday at 1:30 p.m.; Aug. 19 at 8:45 p.m.; Aug. 20 at midnight; Aug. 28 at 7:45 p.m.; Aug. 29 at 4:45 p.m. 

GEEK LOVE
 Fans of Katherine Dunn's novel are still waiting for the long-rumored film version (David Lynch and Tim Burton have both been mentioned as directors), but in the meantime, this adaptation should more than suffice. The cult tale follows a couple of carnival performers who engineer a family of circus freaks by taking drugs to induce birth defects in their children. In this well-received and technically sophisticated production, which was first staged in Atlanta, elaborate prosthetics and puppeteering help create the flipper boy, conjoined twin sisters and an enormous baby named Mumpo the Mountain. Linhart Theater: Saturday at 5:30 p.m.; Aug. 18 at 8 p.m.; Aug. 19 at 3 p.m.; Aug. 20 at 5:15 p.m.; Aug. 21 at 3:30 p.m. 

HOST AND GUEST
 Paata and Irina Tsikurishvili, a married couple from the former Soviet Republic of Georgia, do the kind of work that you hardly ever see in the often frivolous fringe festival -- art with a capital A. Based on a Georgian poem, this movement-intensive show, which combines Chaplinesque mime and classical dance, follows a member of a Muslim tribe who dares to offer shelter to an enemy Christian. The Tsikurishvilis started really raising eyebrows after taking home three prizes at the Helen Hayes Awards, the Tonys of Washington, beating out established heavyweights like Arena Stage and the Shakespeare Theater. Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University: Friday at 5 p.m.; next Sunday at 6:30 p.m.; Aug. 18 at 10:30 p.m.; Aug. 20 at 4 p.m.; Aug. 21 at 8 p.m. 

HOW TO SAVE THE WORLD AND FIND TRUE LOVE -- IN 90 MINUTES
 When Jonathan Karp took over as the editor in chief of Random House imprints in May, he found himself on top of one of the most prestigious perches in all of book publishing. So why is this bigwig writing, of all things, a fringe musical? Doesn't he know that this is more the realm of the unemployed slacker? Well, he can't help himself. ''I love theater,'' he says. ''I always have.'' His pop-infused show, which he describes as a mix of ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and ''The Daily Show,'' imagines how an office romance inside the United Nations could create a global catastrophe. The good early buzz should help the musical draw more than just curious publishing types. Lucille Lortel Theater: Aug. 25 at 1 p.m.; Aug. 26 at 4 p.m.; Aug. 27 at 5:30 p.m.; Aug. 28 at 8:45 p.m.; Aug. 29 at noon. 

YOU'LL HAVE HAD YOUR HOLE
 When Irvine Welsh's gruesome revenge drama, about two skinheads who torture a longtime friend inside an abandoned recording studio, opened in England in 1998, critics were as brutal as the main characters. In fact, the reviews were so harsh -- the critic for The Daily Telegraph called it ''the most obnoxious and contemptible play I have ever sat through'' -- that they inspired a small backlash, as others came to the defense of Mr. Welsh (the author of the novel ''Trainspotting'') and the play's street-tough lyricism and poignant humor. This is its first American production (with Ian Pfister, foreground above, and Zack Calhoon), so judge for yourself. Collective Unconscious: Friday at 7 p.m.; Saturday at 2 p.m.; Aug. 17 at 5:45 p.m.; Aug. 19 at 3 p.m.; Aug. 20 at 10 p.m.; Aug. 21 at 9:15 p.m.; Aug. 27 at 3 p.m.; Aug. 29 at 2 p.m. 

DOG SEES GOD: CONFESSIONS OF A TEENAGE BLOCKHEAD
 What would happen to the Peanuts gang if they ever grew older? Would Lucy start taking Prozac? Would Peppermint Patty come out of the closet? And, of course, the big question: Would Charlie Brown finally give up on kicking that football? If none of this holds any interest, there's still a good reason to see Bert V. Royal's unauthorized parody of Charles M. Schulz's comic strip -- the up-and-coming star Daniel Franzese, better known as Lindsay Lohan's gay friend in ''Mean Girls,'' is in the cast, along with Michael Gladis (at right). SoHo Playhouse: Saturday at 5:30 p.m.; Aug. 18 at 10:15 p.m.; Aug. 22 at noon; Aug. 26 at 3 p.m.; Aug. 28 at 7:45 p.m. 

HARVEY FINKLESTEIN'S SOCK PUPPET SHOWGIRLS
 There are generally two reactions to Paul Verhoeven's famously terrible film about Las Vegas showgirls -- groaning fury at the waste of two precious hours or cackling glee at the landmark of so-bad-it's-good kitsch. If you're in the second camp, don't miss this underground hit from Chicago, which has enough raunchy puppeteering to make the creators of ''Avenue Q'' avert their eyes. It's a condensed, if fairly faithful, version of the 1995 film's original screenplay, with a few improvements, like a scene in which the Cookie Monster, Big Bird and Elmo crudely hoot and holler at a stripper who prances around a tinfoil pole. Best keep the children far away. The Studio at the Cherry Lane Theater: Friday at 10:15 p.m.; Saturday at noon; next Sunday at 7:15 p.m.; Aug. 17 at 5:45 p.m.; Aug. 18 at 3 p.m. 

PITH!
 If you're not Canadian, you probably haven't heard of Stewart Lemoine, but he is one of the best-known fringe artists there is. A veteran of the Edmonton Fringe Festival -- which began in 1982, making it the first fringe in North America -- he is a prolific playwright who specializes in witty, slightly off-kilter dialogue and screwball scenarios. This comedy, which received a stack of rave reviews, follows an adventurous sailor (played by Jeff Haslam, above) who helps a society widow (Davina Stewart, above right) grieve by taking her and her maid (Leona Brausen) on an imaginary journey into the South American jungle. Connelly Theater: Friday at 6:30 p.m.; Aug. 19 at 11:30 p.m.; Aug. 22 at 7:45 p.m.; Aug. 25 at 3 p.m.; Aug 27. at 7:45 p.m.; Aug. 29 at 4:45 p.m. 

BIG TROUBLE IN LITTLE HAZZARD
 An accomplished production team, including Bill Thompson, a producer of last year's fringe hit ''Cats Talk Back,'' and Will Frears, the director of the recent play ''Omnium Gatherum,'' makes this silly-looking sendup of ''The Dukes of Hazzard'' worth a serious look. But if you think this show will just be cheap shots about Daisy Dukes and hicks in big hats, think again. ''It deals with all these complex human emotions and issues: greed, lust, rage, ambition, jealousy, sexual jealousy, the fear of aging,'' Mr. Frears says. ''It's like Chekhov or Ibsen, only with car chases.'' (With Greg Derelian, near right, and Peter Katona at the wheel.) SoHo Playhouse: Friday at 4 p.m.; Aug. 20 at 5:45 p.m.; Aug. 22 at 2:30 p.m.; Aug. 25 at 8 p.m.; Aug. 27 at 5:45 p.m.

HEADLINE: A President's Leading Indicators

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 One economic measure, like the change in gross domestic product, cannot justify a president's policies.
 The current Bush administration's policy of using borrowed money to raise the G.D.P. is like a family using the proceeds of a second mortgage to raise its standard of living. In both cases, the negative impact will be felt later.

John D. LeDell
Basking Ridge, N.J., Aug. 4, 2004
