HEADLINE: Amid Turmoil, an Economic Pickup

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 11 

 BODY:
With its protests and political tumult of the last few years, Venezuela has been anything but hospitable to business.
 But at sprawling car plants in the city of Valencia, southwest of Caracas, production this year is up sharply. Eli Lilly & Company, maker of impotence drugs, Prozac and insulin, is expecting sales to shoot up. The DirectTV Group says the number of subscribers should increase 18 percent this year, to 320,000.
 And Juan Vicente Alvarez, whose family has had a construction company for 34 years, is planning a string of apartment complexes that are its largest projects since 1999. 
 It is all part of an economic rebound that, economists say, could lead to growth rates of 10 to 12 percent this year, nearly double the government's initial forecasts. The rise in Venezuela's economy, Latin America's fourth largest, is helping to drive what the United Nations says will be a 4 percent expansion in Latin America this year, the biggest since 1997.
 For Venezuela's left-leaning government, which has been fending off threats to remain in power, the economy's rebound could not have come a moment too soon. 
 Facing a recall referendum on Sunday that could end President Hugo Chavez's turbulent five years in office, the economic boom -- driven by soaring oil prices that have left Venezuela awash in petro-dollars -- is spurring heavy government spending on social programs that are having the desired effect: solidifying support when the president needs it most.
 But while the government celebrates, Venezuela's economy is anything but healthy, after a two-year contraction that some economists call one of the biggest free falls in Latin America in years. In 2002, the economy fell 8.9 percent, and crumpled again in 2003, by 9.4 percent. 
 Crippled by antigovernment strikes in 2002 that went into 2003, production at Venezuela's large government-owned oil company at one point slowed to a trickle. Companies went out of business, and many people lost their jobs, floating into the country's mushrooming informal economy.
 With only one way to go -- up -- the economy has registered startling growth this year.
 ''It's a statistical bounce since it was going to come back,'' explained Rafael de la Fuente, chief Latin economist for BNP Paribas in New York. ''Still, you're not back at the level you were two years ago. All told, this is still an economy that hasn't recovered.''
 Driven by world oil prices that are approaching $45 a barrel, oil revenues have risen 120 percent in last 12 months, and nonoil revenue has nearly doubled, LatinSource, a network of economists based in New York, said in a recent report.
 The economic indicators, though, gloss over an economy unable to attract much foreign investment or create jobs for the 50 percent of Venezuelan laborers who toil in the informal sector, selling on the street or running unregulated businesses. Hamstrung by stringent exchange controls and an unpredictable political situation, many local businesses have been unable to grow.
 ''Clearly what you're seeing is a normalization of activity at quite a low level,'' said Michael Gavin, chief economist for UBS in Stamford, Conn. ''They recovered from the heart attack, but the cancer is there.''
 Indeed, economic indicators show that Venezuela attracted only $1.4 billion in foreign direct investment in 2003, down from $4.3 billion in 1998, according to Mr. Gavin's calculations.
 The central government is also running deficits as spending rises to $26.9 billion this year from $24.3 billion last year, according to estimates by Credit Suisse First Boston. The budget deficit is expected to be about 5.9 percent of gross domestic product this year, First Boston said, and rise to 6.7 percent next year. The gap was less than 2 percent of gross domestic product in 1999. 
 ''The current fiscal stance is unsustainable,'' said the bank in a report on Aug. 6, explaining that although high oil prices have permitted more spending, the government will be hit hard when prices drop. The report, written after a visit to Venezuela, said that First Boston researchers ''saw nothing during our visit to change our broadly negative long-term view of Venezuela.''
 The Chavez government dismisses such assessments, saying that its social spending generates jobs and that the country's fiscal condition is healthy. Venezuela is, indeed, well regarded for paying its debts on time, and its international reserves have shot up to nearly $24 billion, from $15 billion in 1998.
 ''This is a government that shows it can come back,'' said Ricardo Dorado, vice minister of labor, explaining that much of the country's free fall was brought about by opposition groups. ''There is now a recovery.''
 Signs of a comeback can be found in sectors like auto production, retail sales and, little by little, construction, which is taking its first baby steps after lean years when building practically reached a standstill.
 The Ford Motor Company in Valencia said that about 140 cars and trucks were being built each day -- about 50 percent more than last year -- by 1,600 workers, 450 more than last year.
 In all, the automobile industry in this land of big cars and cheap gas may build 120,000 cars and trucks this year, twice the number of 2003. It falls far short of the 217,000 vehicles made in 2001, but executives say they are pleased nevertheless.
 ''For Ford, this has been an excellent year,'' said Enmanuel Cassingena, president of Ford Andina, which also oversees production in Colombia and Ecuador. With its new compact cars, Ford has a 21.7 percent market share in Venezuela, 5.6 percent more than at this point last year, Mr. Cassingena said.
 ''The sector has rebounded faster than we had thought,'' he said.
 In Caracas, other sectors that have registered upticks include construction, up 19.5 percent in the first quarter; retailing, up 27.9 percent, and transport and storage, which grew 25.3 percent. Manufacturing over all, including car production, increased 50 percent in the first three months.
 Jorge Botti, who represents retailers and runs several businesses, said his 47-year-old family-run company, a hardware wholesaler called Padlock, has expanded into several business lines. He provides high-technology hardware to the telecommunications industry and is opening a big food wholesaler.
 ''It has flourished,'' Mr. Botti said of his business. ''We are being reborn.''
 But under the rosy surface, he explained, is an ailing economy. Some big competitors have gone out of business, a trend seen across the country and leading to a concentration of companies. And he notes that the encouraging economic data this year hide the fact that the growth rates are being compared with the period last year, when the economy was paralyzed and near collapse.
 ''What we have is a debacle -- we have more people and a smaller economy,'' he said. ''The government holds it all up as a success, but what you see is lost business and a lack of competitors.''
 Construction, considered a barometer of the economy, is also in a delicate position. Companies are building schools in the government's drive to bolster education. A metro system, is being built in Los Teques, outside Caracas, and in the capital the subway is being expanded. Some big projects, like a bridge over the Orinoco River and a major highway, are also moving forward.
 Mr. Alvarez, the builder whose company was started in 1970, is embarking on an upscale complex of 300 apartments, called Sun Views, in Caracas and a project of 700 more units in Valencia. But Mr. Alvarez, who also represents realtors, says that is a tepid start.
 In 2003, only 9,000 apartment units and houses were built, down from 92,000 in 1997, according to the leading builders' association in Caracas. In all, construction in 2003 accounted for a third of the economic activity it generated in 2001. The industry has 550,000 workers, down from 1.1 million during the 1970's construction boom.
 Now, with the economy reviving, Mr. Alvarez is somewhat optimistic that his and other companies will soon see better days. But he says there are hurdles of all kinds, from more cautious buyers to a lack of credit to political uncertainty.
 ''There are projects that are ready to get off the ground,'' he said. ''But, of course, the purchasing power of people is not where it should be.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Toys 'R' Us Considers Selling Its Toy Business
Battered by intense competition from discounters like Wal-Mart, Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, announced that it might bow out of the toy business completely. The company, which in its heyday pushed rivals out of business as it grew to more than $11 billion in sales, said that it was considering splitting its toy business and its faster-growing baby supplies division, Babies ''R'' Us, into two separate companies and ''to explore the possible sale of the global toy business.''
 Abandoning the world of Barbie and Lego would be a startling denouement for a company that rose to supremacy during the 1990's and became recognized by the bobbing head of its mascot, Geoffrey the Giraffe. [Page A1.]

Ex-BNP Executives Plead Guilty
Two former executives of BNP Paribas North America, the New York-based unit of the large French bank, pleaded guilty to stealing more than $12 million from their employer. [C7.]

Japan Banks Can Resume Talks
A Tokyo court granted an appeal by UFJ Holdings that clears the way for the struggling Japanese bank to resume merger talks with its larger rival, the Mitusbishi Tokyo Financial Group, in a deal that could create the world's largest bank. [World Business, Section W.]

Gold Fields to Acquire Iamgold
Gold Fields, based in Johannesburg, agreed to buy the Iamgold Corporation, based in Toronto, in a stock swap valued at about $2.1 billion, fending off a competing bid from Golden Star Resources. [World Business, Section W.]

Stewart Company in Acquisitions
Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia plans to announce that it is purchasing Body & Soul magazine along with a newsletter on self-healing. Advertising. [C4.]

A federal judge declined to throw out perjury charges against the Secret Service ink expert who testified for the government at the Martha Stewart trial. [C4.]

Lay Must Wait for Decision on Trial
Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, must wait until the end of September before a judge will decide whether to separate his fraud trial from those of other former officers of the company. [C9.]

Bush Suggests Change in Taxes
President Bush told supporters in Florida that the United States ought to consider replacing income taxes with a national sales tax. [A20.]

Quarterly Profit Falls at Federated
Federated Department Stores, the owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, said that its fiscal second-quarter earnings fell 35 percent as a result of costs to pay down debt and close stores. The company increased its forecast of annual profit. Net income in the three months ended July 31 fell to $78 million, or 43 cents a share, from $120 million, or 64 cents, a year earlier, a sharper drop than analysts had expected. Revenue rose 3.3 percent, to $3.55 billion, the company said. [C2.]

News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said that fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 7.8 percent. [C4.]

Let the Renter of Equipment Beware
Add equipment-leasing deals to the list of financial pitfalls that plague small companies. Small Business. [C8.]

Economics and Islam
Islamic economic principles may sound like just what the Middle East needs. In practice, however, the situation is more complicated. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. [C2.]

HEADLINE: Fears of Isolation as US Airways Cuts Flights

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
Known for its splendid setting at the head of Cayuga Lake, for its frequent appearances on ''best places to live'' lists and for the Cornell University campus perched on the hill above, Ithaca, N.Y., is also a community with an Achilles' heel: it is becoming harder to fly there.
 As recently as 1997, five airlines served the city's pristine jewel box of an airport, Tompkins Regional. Now there is just one, US Airways, and it may not be there much longer.
 On Thursday, the airline delivered some bad news that Ithacans had been bracing for. Come November, the airline will discontinue its four daily flights to Pittsburgh, the US Airways hub where passengers could make connections to most of the country. Nineteen other cities will also lose their Pittsburgh service, US Airways said, as the airline dismantles the hub to concentrate more on point-to-point flying. 
 Ithaca is one of 34 communities, mostly in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states, that are served only by US Airways, an airline that has already been through one bankruptcy since the Sept. 11 attacks and is struggling hard to avoid another. If it fails and is shut down, those 34 airports will be left without scheduled service.
 Smaller cities across the country have depended for decades on the hub-and-spoke system used by US Airways and other airlines for convenient access to air travel. By funneling passengers through their hubs, the airlines were able to provide more frequent service and connections to more destinations than these small markets could otherwise sustain. ''Ithaca really was designed for the hub-and-spoke system,'' said Robert Nicholas, the manager of the city's airport.
 But that system is being undermined by high costs, the financial aftereffects of the deep slump in air travel after Sept. 11 and the growing willingness of passengers to drive farther to reach a city served by a low-fare airline. 
 Robert W. Mann Jr., an industry consultant based in Port Washington, N.Y., said he doubted that many communities would be able to find a replacement for US Airways. Only cities that qualify for federal subsidies under programs like Essential Air Service, which pays airlines to fly to out-of-the-way communities, or that are willing to subsidize flights may get another airline, he said. Otherwise, ''instead of air-service spokes, they will revert to driving spokes,'' Mr. Mann said.
 Service to Ithaca, 57 miles southwest of Syracuse, does not qualify for federal subsidies, and it has been suffering death by a thousand cuts. Tompkins Regional, where carriers like Mohawk, Empire, Allegheny, Piedmont, Commuter and TWA have come and gone over the years, lost US Airways' last rival four years ago, when Continental Airlines left. 
 US Airways stopped flying mainline jets to Ithaca early in 2003, and now offers only its US Airways Express turboprops and regional jets. When the Pittsburgh flights end in November, Ithacans will be able to fly only to Philadelphia or to LaGuardia Airport in New York. 
 US Airways' declining fortunes are a major cause of the cutbacks, but so are local passengers who would rather drive to Syracuse, Rochester or even Buffalo to catch a flight than pay US Airways' relatively high fares. Passenger volume, which peaked in the mid-1990's, has since fallen more than 25 percent. US Airways and the Ithaca airport divided $60,000 in losses on flights to and from Ithaca in 2003 (one-quarter by the airport; the rest by the airline).
 Even Alfred A. Kahn, a former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, often avoids flying from Tompkins Regional. Mr. Kahn was the architect of airline deregulation in the Carter administration, which led the airlines to create the hub-and-spoke networks and start feeder-flight service to scores of cities like Ithaca. 
 At 86, he still cuts a jaunty figure, strolling through Ithaca cane in hand, though he stopped driving after a serious accident two years ago. While he uses the local airport occasionally, he often hires a limousine to take him to Syracuse, where he can fly to Kennedy Airport in New York on JetBlue Airways, the low-fare carrier based in Queens.
 JetBlue's round-trip fare between Syracuse and J.F.K. is about $200, so even after paying $65 each way for the hourlong limo ride, Mr. Kahn saves money compared with US Airways' $550 round-trip fare between Ithaca and LaGuardia. 
 ''The fares are so low and the flights are so pleasant,'' Mr. Kahn said of JetBlue.
 Cornell, the biggest employer in the area, encourages but does not require its staff and faculty to seek the lowest fares when traveling on college business, said Richard McDaniel, associate vice president for campus and business services. Flights from Tompkins Regional are still permitted, Mr. McDaniel said, but Cornell is feeling the pinch of the high fares. ''We don't have a lot of money to burn,'' he said. 
 So, to cut costs and to hedge against the possible loss of air service, the university is starting a bus line linking its Ithaca campus with its medical college in New York City. The 20-seat bus, equipped with tables and ports for laptop computers, will start running on Sept. 7; the fare for the ride, just under five hours each way, will be $149 round-trip. 
 Still, some at the university would rather fly. Mark H. Anbinder, a computer specialist at Cornell, has set up alerts on Travelocity.com, the discount travel Web site, that let him know when US Airways has a fare sale, but he sticks to Tompkins Regional with or without the discounts.
 ''I will pay a premium not to have to drive to Syracuse and spend that three hours in the car,'' he said.
 Rachel Weiner, a senior at Cornell who grew up in Andover, Mass., prefers the air to the highway when she goes home for a weekend, hopping on a 16-seat plane from Ithaca to LaGuardia and then catching the shuttle flight to Boston.
 Flying takes as long as driving, Ms. Weiner said -- about six hours -- but ''the drive is so long and taxing.'' 
 Community leaders have discussed many ideas for increasing passenger traffic, like fare subsidies, marketing campaigns and appeals to airlines to invest in Ithaca. 
 ''How do we reinvent ourselves so that they say, 'Hmm, there's something there?''' asked Barbara Blanchard, a Tompkins County legislator and a member of the local Air Service Task Force.
 The task force, set up in 1997, gained an added sense of urgency when US Airways filed for bankruptcy in 2002 and did not pay fees to the airport for three months. Mr. Nicholas said the airport eventually agreed to accept 10 cents on the dollar for the arrears, a loss that helped knock the airport's operating fund down to about $67,000 from $400,000 in 2001. It is likely to shrink further after the Pittsburgh flights stop.
 Even so, Tompkins Regional remains a point of community pride. The bright and airy terminal, opened in 1994, was a huge improvement over the tiny old cinderblock structure, whose baggage claim amounted to a garage door and a chain-link fence. The first half-hour is free in the short-term parking lot, and an official greeter scurries up with a baggage cart, also free, to meet travelers who are dropped off at the curb.
 Between flights last week, the airport's three US Airways counters stood empty; one airline employee sat reading, while two others looked up with smiles as a handful of people strolled in. There was nothing resembling a line at the Hertz and Avis car rental desks, nor any wait at the security checkpoint -- heaven for a harried traveler, perhaps, but not for Mr. Nicholas. ''I'd rather it was a zoo,'' he said as he led a tour earlier this month.
 Travelers encounter no snags in the terminal, but all too many on the tarmac. As US Airways has shed employees, it has repeatedly had problems finding crews for commuter flights to Ithaca and other small cities, resulting in frequent cancellations and delays. 
 That problem, and the shrinking number of destinations offered by US Airways, has prompted even some of the airport's biggest fans to turn elsewhere. Jean McPheeters, president of the Ithaca Chamber of Commerce, travels frequently to Duluth, Minn., a city US Airways does not serve. She generally drives to Syracuse to catch a Northwest Airlines flight.
 Ms. McPheeters said she was confident that Ithaca could find a replacement for US Airways if necessary. With its scenic beauty and a stable economy dominated by Cornell, Ms. McPheeters said, Ithaca could make a persuasive pitch. Her own preference, she said, would be a low-fare carrier like JetBlue or Independence Air, rather than one of the traditional airlines. 
 But Mr. McDaniel said that community leaders knew they faced competition. Some cities that are losing US Airways service have already formed a lobbying group, the Coalition for Disadvantaged Airports. 
 ''We have a strong economic base in our little region,'' Mr. McDaniel said. ''But other people have wonderful stories to tell, too, so we had better get moving.''

HEADLINE: Pataki Threatens to Veto Budget Items He Dislikes

BYLINE: By AL BAKER

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 12 

 BODY:
With more than a third of the year gone by, New York State finally has a budget. But as details began to filter out Thursday, Gov. George E. Pataki warned that he would veto some of the Legislature's spending proposals.
 Hours after the State Legislature signed off Wednesday night on a $101.3 billion budget that is the most expensive -- and the tardiest -- in state history, the governor attacked the spending plan as a financially irresponsible document that ''spends too much and reforms too little.'' 
 Mr. Pataki, a Republican in his third term as governor, vowed to veto the parts of the budget that he disagreed with, once he and his staff have examined the tens of thousands of appropriations in 12 budget bills. He recalled how, in 1998, he moved similarly in striking 1,000 items that lawmakers had added to his original budget plan.
 ''I have very profound concerns about how this budget affects the fiscal health of this state,'' Mr. Pataki said at a morning news conference in the State Capitol's ornate Red Room. ''We have real concerns that it creates a massive increase'' in projected future shortfalls. ''In the budget I proposed,'' he said, those shortfalls ''were manageable.'' 
 In response, New York's two top legislators, Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader in the State Senate, and Sheldon Silver, Democratic speaker of the State Assembly, each portrayed the budget they passed as solid, warranting no vetoes. They neither promised nor ruled out overrides, at least for now. 
 So, while it was still uncertain which parts of the budget would become law, the full breadth of the leaders' priorities became clear, but only after the votes. 
 On top of a $99.8 billion budget that Mr. Pataki proposed in January, the lawmakers approved about $850 million more in spending that officials said was primarily supported by higher-than-anticipated state tax revenues. While the governor proposed $1.1 billion in new taxes and fees, the lawmakers enacted $700 million.
 The Legislature's plan relies in part on $459 million generated by an extension of the sales tax on clothing under $110; on nursing home owners paying $125 million more in higher assessments; and on gamblers generating $93 million in new revenue by playing more Quick Draw poker games in bars and restaurants.
 The lawmakers also added new long-term debt to the budget. It added $600 million for construction and maintenance of state and city universities over the next five years, bringing that total to nearly $4 billion. It also enacted the governor's plan to raise more than $350 million through new borrowing for private and public colleges, officials said.
 To curb skyrocketing health care costs, the budget assumes from localities the cost of the state's Family Health Plus program, which provides health insurance for certain low-income families. 
 And proving that a budget is more than figures in ledger book, the budget will have a tangible impact: those who like a glass of pinot noir with Sunday dinner may be happy to know that liquor stores will be able to stay open seven days a week, not six, in an effort to drive $2 million in additional tax revenue into state coffers. Part of the budget, though, seemed designed to get around the governor's veto threats. For instance, lawmakers passed $170 million in spending on their own pet projects, and $30 million for the governor's. But to discourage a veto, they linked the spending to money Mr. Pataki planned to use for economic development and job creation. Only half of the cash for pet projects is set to go out this year. 
 The budget was enacted 133 days after the state's April 1 deadline, and was approved with little debate late Wednesday night. Budget watchdogs shook their heads.
 ''New York State's handling of this year's budget is a landmark case of lousy government,'' said Diana Fortuna, the head of the Citizens Budget Commission. ''Its last-minute, late-night passage prevented legislators and the public from understanding what was being adopted.''
 Analysts quickly did the math, but in the opaque world of Albany budgeting, a debate ensued over who had the correct numbers; none of the top elected officials counted the money the same way. Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bruno bickered over whose projection of actual spending last year was closer to the mark, an argument certain to shade a potential veto and override fight going forward.
 The lateness of the budget also had lawmakers wondering if the old sticks meant to prompt passage of a timely budget -- namely, withholding paychecks -- were an adequate incentive. Senator David A. Paterson, a Manhattan Democrat, said he got 11 checks worth about $20,000 on Thursday and cited it as proof that withholding salaries from lawmakers was not an effective way to stop gridlock. Rather, he said, budgets should be treated like round-the-clock labor negotiations.
 ''If you want to hurt a politician you don't take their money, you take their time,'' he said. ''You keep legislators away from their constituents for two weeks and you will have inmates in an asylum and it's true.''

HEADLINE: On a Fast Track: Power, Turmoil and a Crashing End

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS

 BODY:
Growing up in the blue-collar belly of central New Jersey, the son of a former Marine drill sergeant who struggled as a traveling salesman, James Edward McGreevey was always pushing himself toward greatness, eager for self-sacrifice and hungry for the approval of others.
 ''Our lad of great expectations,'' is how the father once described his only son. From his stint on the high school spirit committee to his rapid rise through the local politics of Middlesex County, Mr. McGreevey's political savvy and his back-slapping charm opened doors, earned him allies and helped win elections. He was president of his high school class, became a state official at 28 and made his first bid for elected office at 32. At 36, he was both the mayor of Woodbridge and a state senator. 
 ''With his ambition and drive, I think all of us could have imagined him becoming governor,'' said Jerry Rabadeau, his economics teacher at St. Joseph's High School.
 But few of Mr. McGreevey's early admirers, if any, could have imagined how and why he would have to stop being governor: declaring publicly yesterday that he was gay, and that he had, in effect, led something of a double life, one that included an affair with a man he had once put on the state payroll.
 Still, some friends, colleagues and political observers said it was possible that Mr. McGreevey's great ambitions, and considerable power, might have convinced him that he could successfully keep his other life, and the affair, secret.
 Ross K. Baker, a political scientist at Rutgers University, said Mr. McGreevey's quick ascension may have made him feel invincible, despite his obvious inner turmoil. ''He was shaped by the political culture of Middlesex County, where there was no Republican opposition,'' Mr. Baker said. ''When you come out of a place like that, you feel unassailable because you have people protecting you.''
 But if the details of Mr. McGreevey's reasons for resigning were a shock to some, and a cause for sadness to others, they were part of a larger legacy of disappointment that Mr. McGreevey will leave when he quits the governor's mansion as promised on Nov. 15, supporters and adversaries alike said.
 After campaigning on a platform to clean up the culture of political dysfunction and inside dealing in Trenton, he angered many Republicans with a series of appointments that some said smacked of payback and patronage. Members of his administration and inner circle have left office under investigation.
 And in recent weeks, Mr. McGreevey's image as a possible reformer has been further marred by a corruption scandal involving two men who were key fund-raisers. And finally, even legislative allies have expressed dismay at recent public policy initiatives he has undertaken or supported -- moves they say betray his most basic principles.
 But on the day Mr. McGreevey announced his resignation, even his opponents were reluctant to harp on his missteps and failings. ''In many respects this is almost like a death in the family,'' Senator Diane B. Allen, a South Jersey Republican who has been one of the governor's more vocal critics. ''We may be Republicans and Democrats, or we may be from the north or the south, but right now we're all in this together.''
 Among the deepest disappointments, many said, were his failed effort to drastically overhaul New Jersey's notoriously troubled campaign finance system, and a recent legislative proposal that would make it easier for developers to build.
 Some supporters, though, loyally insisted that Mr. McGreevey's time in office was not without significant triumphs: his efforts to improve the state's troubled E-ZPass system and the modest property-tax rebate, paid for by the state's wealthiest residents, that he pushed through against considerable odds.
 ''McGreevey accomplished a lot that benefited working people and the middle class,'' said Phyllis Salowe-Kaye, the executive director of New Jersey Citizen Action, the state's largest consumer watchdog group. ''To us, he's been a courageous fighter.''
 James Florio, the former governor and a Democrat, said he had been looking forward to Mr. McGreevey taking on one of the thorniest issues facing New Jersey residents: property tax reform.
 Mr. McGreevey, after narrowly losing to Gov. Christie Whitman in 1997, found his opening in 2001, when Mrs. Whitman left office early to serve as Environmental Protection Agency administrator in the newly elected Bush administration. After the main Republican contender, acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco pulled out of the race under a cloud of allegations about lapsed ethics, Mr. McGreevey handily defeated Bret D. Schundler, a Republican. 
 Buoyed by his victory, Mr. McGreevey began his term in 2002 brimming with confidence and promising New Jerseyeans that his fiscally responsible brand of populism offered them boundless possibilities. In his inaugural address he invoked Abraham Lincoln and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., promising to rein in a huge budget deficit, fight terrorism and revamp the public school system -- all without resorting to broad-based tax increases or excessive borrowing.
 But nearly as soon as he took office, Mr. McGreevey showed a surprising and persistent knack for mishandling the tricky political landscape of the state capital. He angered powerful Democratic Party bosses by reneging on promises to finance their pet projects, and in several instances offered the same coveted appointment to several candidates at the same time. He backed away from his promise not to raise taxes, and set off a flurry of complaints by floating a short-lived proposal to raise property taxes in low-income neighborhoods.
 Most embarrassing was Mr. McGreevey's parade of ill-fated appointments: his first chief of staff and chief counsel resigned amid allegations that they misused their office; his state police director was forced out after accusations that he interfered with an investigation into his background; one of Mr. McGreevey's nominees for the State Supreme Court was forced to withdraw from consideration because she drove to her background interview with a suspended license and was the subject of a bench warrant for failing to pay traffic tickets. Even Mr. McGreevey's choice for poet laureate, Amiri Baraka, turned into a headache when he read an inflammatory poem suggesting that the Israelis had received advanced warning of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. 
 But for all that, many in the state were left yesterday grappling with the speed of his fall.
 ''I'm in a state of shock and disbelief,'' said State Senator Shirley K. Turner, a Democrat from South Jersey. ''I think it's a courageous act on his part and it must have taken a lot of soul searching to reach that point, because I know how much he loves his job and how much he loves the state of New Jersey.''


CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 13 about the political career of Gov. James E. McGreevey referred incorrectly in some copies to Zulima Farber, a candidate for a State Supreme Court appointment in 2003 who had a history of traffic violations. The governor abandoned his plans to nominate her; she was never a nominee. 
 The article also referred incorrectly in some copies to the process by which Amiri Baraka became the state's poet laureate in August 2002, an appointment widely criticized after he gave a reading of a poem implying that Israel knew in advance about the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. He was chosen by a committee appointed by two state arts groups, not by Mr. McGreevey.

HEADLINE: The Absolutely Noirest of the Noir

BYLINE: By DAVE KEHR

 BODY:
Last week's release of Michael Mann's new urban thriller, ''Collateral,'' set a lot of critics, including Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott of The New York Times, to thinking about that particular brand of film noir native to Los Angeles. Mr. Mann's film, like many of the L.A. noirs before it, presents the city in its sinister, nocturnal mode, a landscape from which most human figures have vanished, to be replaced by gliding four-wheeled fortresses and shadowy palm trees waving against a purple sky. 
 Despite Mr. Mann's honest efforts, the ultimate L.A. noir remains Robert Aldrich's 1955 ''Kiss Me Deadly,'' which will close a series called ''Paradise (Lost): Los Angeles on Film'' with a screening at 1 p.m. on Sunday at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens. (Mr. Mann's 1995 ''Heat'' will be shown at 3:30.) 
 Working from one of the notoriously trashy Mike Hammer novels by Mickey Spillane, Aldrich plainly couldn't stand his hero, a thuggish private eye played with a permanent leer by the Broadway transplant Ralph Meeker. Aldrich's Mike Hammer is a sort of low, cunning animal let loose in a cultural landscape he knows nothing about (emphasized by the film's frequent references to classical music, romantic poetry and modern art) and will eventually come close to annihilating when his blundering investigation of a murder leads him to a scientist smuggling atomic secrets. 
 Filmed partly amid the mix of crumbling Victorian mansions and low-rise office buildings that was the Bunker Hill neighborhood (destroyed to make room for downtown development in the 1960's), ''Kiss Me Deadly'' imagines the city as a gothic nightmare. (See also Mr. Aldrich's ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'') Not for Aldrich are Mr. Mann's carefully aestheticized images of a city softly glowing at night; the night skies of ''Kiss Me Deadly'' have the darkness and coldness of anthracite. Like ''Collateral,'' the film gives a sense of community consisting of isolated pockets of warmth and light, connected by endless, empty streets. But where Mr. Mann's film alludes to a whole world of night workers -- cabbies, thieves, cops and lawyers -- Aldrich's characters are frightened, isolated individuals, holed up by themselves in dank apartments. 
 Aldrich, a New York liberal (and a member of the Rockefeller family), puts as much distance as possible between himself and his Paleolithic protagonist -- enough that the French critic Jacques Lourcelles has described ''Kiss Me Deadly'' as a turning point in American cinema, from classical sincerity to modernist irony. The film is structured as a series of semi-lucid moments between Hammer's frequent blackouts, caused by car wrecks and pistol whippings, as if his were a consciousness capable only of sporadic illumination, like one of the flickering neon signs seen in the backgrounds.
 Always acting in narrowly defined self-interest, Aldrich's Hammer is the postwar American on the make, unconcerned with ideals, who is chasing dames and dollars with equal, unthinking desire. Next to him, even Mr. Mann's buttoned-down professional killer, played by Tom Cruise, seems as professionally compassionate as a group therapy leader, gently pushing the cabdriver played by Jamie Foxx to follow his bliss (and open the limousine service he's always dreamed of). There is no room for redemption in ''Kiss Me Deadly.'' The only cure for what ails this urban landscape is spelled out in the film's literally explosive finale. 
 ''Paradise (Lost): Los Angeles on Film'' runs through Sunday at the American Museum of the Moving Image, 36-01 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. Museum admission: $10; 65+ and students, $7.50; ages 5 to 18, $5. Free for members and children 4 and younger and for everyone on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m.(screenings extra). Information: (718) 784-0077 or www.movingimage.us.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Ralph Meeker, playing the leering, blundering gumshoe in Robert Aldrich's 1955 ''Kiss Me Deadly,'' being worked over by thugs. (Photo by Universal Pictures)

LENGTH: 3144 words

HEADLINE: 'Black' Comes in Many Shadings

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
WHEN the Studio Museum in Harlem introduced a group of young African-American artists in the show called ''Freestyle'' a few years ago, the curator, Thelma Golden, called them post-black artists, and caused a ruckus. She was describing artists who didn't feel obliged to refer to ethnicity or racial history in their work or, if they did, were inclined to distance themselves from the references, put them in quotes -- ''race,'' ''power'' -- and so on.
 Ms. Golden was making a suggestion, offering an opportunity, opening a door rather than closing one. But she hit a nerve and got a lot of people thinking about exactly what black art is and might be. Did blackness reside in subject matter? In style? Did the ethnic background of the artist justify, even require the use of the label, even if the art itself was, say, abstract? Other questions arose. In what way was African-American art African? And what does ''American'' mean, anyway, in a country whose demographics are all over the world map? 
 However you define it, there is a surprising amount of black and post-black art around at present. I say surprising because only a decade or so ago mainstream shows devoted to black artists were rare events, more often than not confined to the month of February. But last week, on a day trip from New York City to Baltimore, with stops in Newark and Wilmington, Del., I could take in four museum exhibitions of work by African-Americans, as well as some gallery shows and an unusual museum devoted to African-American cultural history. Each offered something different: black art by white artists, African-American art by African artists, examples of black power abstraction, and solid proof that post-black art has been part of the American picture for almost a century, and probably longer.
 You can get a bird's-eye view of that century in the survey called ''African-American Masters: Highlights From the Smithsonian American Art Museum'' at the Delaware Art Museum in Wilmington. It's one of several shows that have been culled from the Smithsonian's deep closets and sent out on the road while the American Art Museum receives a makeover. With 50 paintings, sculptures and photographs on hand, ranging in date from 1913 to 1996, in style from figurative realism to abstraction, and in theme from urban cityscapes to floral still lifes, the show explodes ''African-American'' as a descriptive term. Much of the work depicts scenes from African-American life, but that life is far from uniform. As seen here, it encompasses Virginia farmers and opera singers, bow-tied black Muslims in Harlem and bikers in a Maryland park who, with their Afros and attitude, could be the Jeff, Gene, Geronimo and Bop of Gwendolyn Brooks's poem ''The Leaders.'' (''Hardly Belafonte, King, Black Jesus, Stokley, Malcolm X or Rap. Their country is a Nation on no map.'')
 Certain artists in the show spent careers shifting between black and nonblack subjects and styles in their art. William H. Johnson paints deceptively simple figures of rural American blacks on their way to church, but also woozily Expressionist scenes of the French Riviera. Similarly, Lois Mailou Jones (1905-98) moved between Neo-Impressionist landscapes and the elegantly cubistic image of an African mask seen here.
 The black content of Hughie Lee-Smith's ''Stranger'' (1957-58), with its scene of a pale-skinned man standing alone against a bleak landscape, was retrospective. The exhibition catalog tells us that it was only when the artist saw the picture 30 years after painting it that he understood it to be a personal emblem of his own alienation as a black man. That's when he gave it its title.

Blackness and Abstraction
 Then there is the question of blackness and abstraction. In the early 1960's, several African-American abstract painters who wanted to contribute to the civil rights effort formed a group called Spiral and shifted to figurative work. Romare Bearden (1912-88) was one of them, and he never turned back. Felrath Hines (1913-1993) was another member of the group, but he went the other way, further into abstraction. His big hard-edge geometric ''Yellow and Gray'' (1976) is one of the show's most striking entries, in part because it looks like nothing else. Possibly that is why Hines still holds only a marginal spot in the history books.
 As an aside, it's worth noting that yet another Spiral member, ''Charles Spinky Alston (1907-77), has a mini-retrospective at Bill Hodges Gallery in Manhattan. Like Hines, he started working figuratively, then turned abstract. Mr. Hodges suggests, in a slender catalog, that Alston was operating on what W. E. B. Du Bois termed a ''double consciousness,'' by which blacks saw themselves as they were seen in the larger society: as American but also as ''different'' Americans. He decided he didn't want to be perceived as a black painter, with the strictures that could impose; for that reason he went with an ethnically neutral abstraction.
 Actually, abstraction can have a specific ethnic and political content. In Norman Lewis's ''Evening Rendezvous'' (1962), in Wilmington, what look like fleet white vertical paint strokes turn out to be tiny hooded figures surrounded by red flames and blue smoke. But such hybrid work is uncommon, and abstract work by African-Americans has on the whole been badly neglected. Occasional surveys turn up; but no major museum has touched this material in an in-depth way.
 Further complicating matters of art and ethnicity is a second, smaller show at the Delaware Art Museum, '' 'Glorious Dignity': Drawings of the Montgomery Bus Boycott by Harvey Dinnerstein and Burton Silverman.'' The two artists went to Alabama in 1956 to record the unfolding drama of one of the great early civil rights protests. They drew portraits of the boycott leaders in action, among them the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whose words give the show its title. But most of their pictures are of Montgomery's black citizens sitting in court or walking home or to work or to the market, as the boycotters did for more than a year. 
 The 46 drawings in the show, detailed but unfancy, are worthy visual complements to Jo Ann Gibson Robinson's renowned memoir of the boycott. Mrs. Robinson was a black Montgomerian; Mr. Dinnerstein and Mr. Silverman are white New Yorkers. But who is to say that their Montgomery drawings are not, in an important sense, African-American images?
 The ambiguity of blackness is the subject of ''One True Thing, Meditations on Black Aesthetics,'' an intricate, self-challenging solo show of work from the last five years by Kerry James Marshall, at the Baltimore Museum of Art. Based in Chicago, Mr. Marshall is best known as a figurative painter of emblematic narratives about black urban life and the spoiled utopia of the 1960's. Although he includes paintings in the show, much of the work is sculpture, photography and video. And in stretching himself formally, he generates a dizzying flow of ideas that alternately confirm and question the continuing viability of something called black art.
 A few pieces directly address historical facts: slavery, lynchings, the killing of four black girls by a terrorist bomb in Birmingham, Ala., where Mr. Marshall was born in 1955. These are realities that define black American history as different but inseparable from white American history. You may or may not believe that they are still operative in the present. Mr. Marshall believes they are. Does this make them a worthy subject for art? Yes. Are they Mr. Marshall's subjects? Sometimes.
 But most of his art is in the interrogative rather than declarative mode. He is fundamentally a realist, and therefore a questioner of symbols and illusion. In the diptych titled ''Color-Blind Test,'' he paints bust-length images of a man and a woman in the center of Marcus Garvey's Black Nationalist flag. The figures give a raised-fist salute, emblematic of 1960's black power. The colors of the flag are emblematic, too: red for blood, green for Africa and black for black skin. But the potent energy they once represented is defused. The flag's colors are reduced to wan pastels; the faces and fists half-obscured by an all-over polka-dot pattern. The dots derive from a scientific test for color-blindness; here they threaten to turn icons of past radicalism into festive decoration.
 The best work in this show, though, is a series of ink drawings for a comic strip called ''Rythm Mastr'' that the artist began in 1999. The title character is a kind of black superman who comes to the aid of a young boy trapped in a crime-ridden inner-city neighborhood. He teaches the boy how to bring a collection of traditional African sculptures to life through the sound of drumming, and to use the animated sculptures as a positive force.
 So, Africa and America, good and evil, fantasy and reality join forces here, as do past and future. Mr. Marshall has said that with the work in this exhibition he is leaving the civil rights era behind as a theme. He's done very well by it. And how great to know that one of our best moral thinkers will be turning his history-painter's eye on where we are now and where we are headed.

History in Three Dimensions
 African-American history is brought to life through sculpture in another Baltimore institution, the National Great Blacks in Wax Museum. Established in a storefront in 1983 by Elmer P. and Joanne Martin, and now occupying three floors of a building in East Baltimore, the museum is Madame Tussaud's with a message: it illustrates African-American history, from a walk-in tableau of a ship packed with manacled slaves, to ultra-realistic figures of contemporary politicians and sports heroes.
 The realism turns gruesome in depictions of lynching, torture and other forms of racial violence in a basement gallery, and the temptation to treat the museum as a species of kitsch is cut short. What you're looking at in these painted wax images of mutilated bodies and severed limbs is a literal, clinical visualization of the dark historical realities alluded to in Mr. Marshall's work, and the images are intense. 
 In this museum, which makes no claims to being an art museum, African-American identity is defined by history, and the dynamic of that history is clear. Black people suffered because of racism, and survived and achieved success despite it. Over all, the emphasis is on achievement, though any note of triumphalism is subdued. The afternoon I was there, the place was crowded with visitors, far more than I saw anywhere else. The museum recently bought all the buildings on its block and plans to expand.
 To learn something about the African part of the African-American experience, I recommend a look at the Ethiopian paintings and sculptures at the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore. Although this is the largest Ethiopian collection outside Addis Abba, it is still very small. It is also very fabulous.
 The Atlantic slave trade operated primarily out of West Africa, but Ethiopia to the east has played an important role in African-American identity. The oldest Christian country in Africa and a charismatic presence in the biblical psalms, it is evoked in the words ''Abyssinia'' and ''Zion'' found in the names of African-American churches. The Jamaican politico-religious movement Rastafarianism is named for the Ethiopian emperor Haile Selassie (1892-1975), who was also called Ras (Prince) Tafar. It was under his rule that slavery was made illegal in Ethiopia. Rastafarians believed that all the people in the African diaspora would in the end return to Africa and find a paradise on earth.
 Despite its symbolic significance, the Christian art of Ethiopia has only recently gained attention in the United States, largely thanks to the 1993 exhibition ''African Zion: The Sacred Art of Ethiopia,'' which appeared at the Schomburg Center in Harlem and later at the Walters. With its icon paintings, processional crosses and illuminated gospels, it is a wondrous art, a tight weave of Byzantine, Italian Renaissance and indigenous traditions that has a look and a spirit entirely its own.
 More of this material is also on view this summer at the Newark Museum in ''Objects of Devotion: Traditional Art of Ethiopia.'' This exquisite little gathering is meant to complement a second show, ''My Ethiopia: Recent Paintings by Wosene Worke Kosrof,'' in which an Africa-America connection is updated and made concrete.
 Organized by Christa Clarke, the museum's new curator of art from Africa, the Americas and the Pacific, it brings together 14 recent paintings by Wosene (as he refers to himself professionally). He was born in 1950, came to the United States in 1978 after Haile Selassie had been deposed, and is now an American citizen. He studied at Howard University in Washington with the influential American artist Jeff Donaldson, who died this year. 

Glittering Colors
 Like ''Rythm Mastr,'' Wosene links African and American culture, but in a different way, by blending written letters from the Amharic language of Ethiopia with Western-style gestural painting. The results are abstract, but richly coded, with fractured texts, personal symbols (the shape of his childhood home in ''Words of Memory'') and a palette of jewel-like colors -- reds, yellows and greens -- associated with Ethiopian icon paintings.
 Is Wosene an African artist? An American artist? Modern? Postmodern? He is all of these. And however indirectly, his art is a reminder that African art may borrow elements of modern Western style, but in absolutely essential ways, Western modernist art originated in Africa. The link is forged yet again in the work of the young Kenyan-born artist Wangechi Mutu, one of three participants in this year's artist-in-residence show at the Studio Museum in Harlem. Dave McKenzie and William Villalongo are the others. All three were born in the 1970's; they are members -- in excellent standing, I would say -- of Ms. Golden's post-black generation.

Playing With Racial Identity
 In this show, organized by Christine Y. Kim, assistant curator at the museum, black racial identity is everywhere, but collaged, massaged, spoofed, battered, sliced up, sent up, and given Frankensteinian forms, sweetly monstrous. In Mr. Villalongo's crisp paintings, an interracial crew of putti cavort in dense jungles and on Mars. Ms. Mutu mixes clipped magazine images of fashion models and machines with painting to create a species of bionic banshees who seem to live in grasslands and wear leopard-skin scarves.
 Mr. McKenzie, much of whose work is conceptual and performance-based, makes a deceptively light-handed thing of his identity as a black man. For a show at the Queens Museum, he created a pinata version of himself, hung it from the ceiling and let someone smash it open. As seen on video, the eager youngsters on hand who scramble for the goodies that spilled out are oblivious to the lynching reference. 
 With a bit of editing magic, Mr. McKenzie also manages to insert himself prominently in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. And throughout his Studio Museum stay he has periodically walked the streets of Harlem dressed in a business suit and wearing a Bill Clinton head, as if to make up for the fact that the neighborhood's most prominent nonblack tenant seems hardly ever to be around. In his Clinton guise, he has been greeted with both cheers and jeers, and sometimes mistaken for the man himself. With artists like Mr. McKenzie around, a shrewd critical take on race and politics will never be wanting.
 Nor should it be. Race, as a concept, however artificial, is reinforced and manipulated at every level of American society. The idea of post-black, intended to expand freedom of choice, carries potentially troubling implications in light of the recent revisionist push for color-blindness in matters of social and economic policy, a development some see as a reassertion of white power.
 Even in the art world, despite the present raised visibility for black artists, a token system is still in effect, requiring them to seek support in racially specific contexts and to concentrate on certain kinds of art. Indeed, a survey like the one you are reading is as much a part of the problem as it is of the solution. And what is that solution? Artists keep making art; we keep looking at what they make; and we all think together as hard as we can.

On the Trail

The exhibitions in Holland Cotter's Critic's Notebook article:

''AFRICAN-AMERICAN MASTERS: HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE SMITHSONIAN AMERICAN ART MUSEUM'' and '' 'GLORIOUS DIGNITY': DRAWINGS OF THE MONTGOMERY BUS BOYCOTT BY HARVEY DINNERSTEIN AND BURTON SILVERMAN,'' Delaware Art Museum, Bank One Center on the Riverfront, 800 South Madison Street, Wilmington. Through Sept. 5 (302) 571-9590. HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rise as Initial Jobless Claims Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
United States retail sales rose last month and initial jobless claims unexpectedly declined to the lowest level in five weeks, according to reports released yesterday, signs that the economic expansion regained momentum in the third quarter.
 Retail sales increased 0.7 percent, to an annual rate of $336.5 billion, as Americans spent more on cars and furniture, the Commerce Department said. June sales fell 0.5 percent instead of the 1.1 percent drop first reported. 
 The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits for the first time fell by 4,000, to 333,000 last week, the Labor Department said, the second consecutive week they showed a decline. The median forecast was for claims to rise to 340,000. The four-week moving average fell to 339,250 from 343,500.
 Economists had expected retail sales to rise 1.2 percent. The lower-than-expected result was countered in part by the revision to June, economists said. Retail sales account for almost 60 percent of all consumer spending.
 Auto sales rose in July as automakers increased discounts after cars and light trucks sold in June at the slowest pace in six years. Sales at automobile dealerships and parts stores rose 2.4 percent last month after falling 3 percent the month earlier. Excluding vehicles and parts, July sales rose 0.2 percent after rising 0.3 percent a month earlier. 
 Furniture sales increased 1.1 percent after rising 2.6 percent the previous month. Sales at department stores and other general merchandise outlets rose 1 percent last month after falling 0.2 percent in June. Sales at clothing and accessory stores fell 0.1 percent after declining 0.5 percent.
 Sales at electronics and appliance stores rose 0.2 percent in July. Purchases at sporting goods, hobby, book and music outlets advanced 1.3 percent while sales at food and beverage stores increased 0.1 percent. Sales at restaurants and bars rose 0.6 percent.
 Purchases excluding autos and building materials, the category used in the Commerce Department's calculation of personal consumption in its report on gross domestic product, rose 0.4 percent after rising 0.2 percent in June.
 Consumer spending was forecast to rise at a 3.2 percent annual rate in the third quarter, based on the median estimate of 48 economists polled by Bloomberg News. Spending rose 1 percent in the second quarter, the slowest pace since the 2001 recession.
 In another report yesterday, the Labor Department said that United States companies paid 0.2 percent more for imported goods and materials last month than in June, as prices for oil, chemicals and metals rose. The increase in the import price index, the ninth in the last 10 months, followed a 0.1 percent decrease in June, the Labor Department said in Washington.

HEADLINE: Fed Cites Inflation and Wages for June Increase

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Higher inflation, business confidence and compensation costs prompted Federal Reserve policy makers to raise the benchmark interest rate for the first time in four years on June 30, minutes of the meeting showed.
 ''Members focused particular attention on the outlook for inflation,'' according to minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, released yesterday. ''Factors cited in this regard included large increases in prices of energy and intermediate materials, both of which appeared to be passing through at least in part to core consumer prices.'' 
 The minutes show that Fed members were committed to returning the overnight bank lending rate to a level more consistent with stable prices, economists said. The same view appeared to prevail this week, when the Fed on Tuesday raised the rate another 0.25 percentage points to 1.5 percent, the economists said.
 The Federal Reserve voted unanimously to raise the rate a quarter-point to 1.25 percent in June after holding it for a year at the lowest level since 1958. The Fed increased the rate again this week even after a Labor Department report on Friday showed a gain of 32,000 jobs, the weakest this year and about an eighth of the forecast.
 At the June meeting, members were divided on the outlook for higher prices. Some expected a slow decrease in unemployed workers, steady long-term inflation expectations, productivity gains and ''one-time price increases.''
 Other members ''tended to emphasize the changes in business attitudes and expectations, the strength in labor compensation, and the tendency for underlying inflation trends to be subject to considerable momentum that was unlikely to be reversed quickly.''
 Policy makers again debated the use of language as a tool to signal the path of interest rates. The phrase ''measured'' remained in the June statement, and members appended it with a new sentence that stated the committee's commitment to respond to higher prices.
 ''The persistence of solid gains in output and employment along with indications of some increase in inflation were seen as warranting a first step in the process of removing policy accommodation,'' the minutes said. ''A more aggressive pace toward reaching a neutral policy stance might be called for so as to provide assurance of containing emerging inflationary pressures and averting the potential need for greater tightening over time.''
 The Fed said in its June meeting that the risks to sustained growth and of higher inflation were ''roughly equal.'' The minutes note that some members viewed the risks tilted toward higher inflation if the committee did not begin a cycle of higher rates.

HEADLINE: Counting Medals in Athens

 BODY:
The Olympic Games are back again, and many of us will stay glued to our television sets for the next two weeks, joining the rest of the world in rooting for the home teams and waiting for that memorable human drama: the star runner who stumbles or the tiny gymnast who nails a landing on a sore ankle. Inevitably, we'll also be hoping for some Cinderella moments, like an underdog Greek who captures the marathon, or more stellar performances by the beleaguered Iraqi soccer team, which won an upset victory yesterday.
 American athletes don't get to be Cinderellas -- it's hard to equate growing up in the world's economic and military superpower with sitting around in the Olympic ashes. NBC commentators will give the home audience the back stories of hardship, injury and personal trauma behind our national team members, but the rest of the globe will probably find it hard to sympathize. 
 While many countries turn a local bronze medal winner into a national hero, our top contenders will be judged disappointments if they fail to come back with a chest full of gold. Given all the speculation that the American swimmer Michael Phelps may get a record eight medals, there's a distinct possibility that Mr. Phelps may wind up feeling terrible if he wins only three or four. 
 The greatest moments in Olympic history are so thrilling that they transcend any thought of the countries involved. But for the rest of the time, overtones of nationality are omnipresent, from the opening ceremonies, where the teams march under their national flags, to the unofficial but much-discussed national medal counts. Almost everyone expects the United States to dominate the medal hunt -- with 111 medals, including 38 gold, according to Sports Illustrated, or 119 medals and 50 gold, according to USA Today. Both reached their judgments the old-fashioned way, by analyzing strengths of individual competitors. The United States Olympic Committee has set 100 medals as its goal, a target presumably put low enough to allow for unexpected setbacks.
 There is another, more humbling way to look at the medal counts, an approach that ignores sports statistics and looks instead at the size and wealth of a nation as key predictors of how many medals it will win. A Dartmouth professor's model factors in population and resources and then adds in past performance in the Olympics and an extra bonus for being the host country. Its creators claim 96 percent accuracy in predicting medal counts for the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, including perfect accuracy in forecasting that the United States would win 97 medals, 39 of them gold. For this year's Olympics, the model predicts a slight falloff for the United States, to 93 medals and 37 gold. 
 If the size-wealth model really works, the fairest way to judge national winners would be to figure out how well a country's athletes performed in light of that nation's resources. By that yardstick, Japan, with a huge economy, and India, with a huge population, would look like perennial underachievers, while sports-crazy Australia and Cuba might well claim to be the real Olympic medal champions.

HEADLINE: Africa's Health-Care Brain Drain

 BODY:
As Africa tries to fight AIDS, the single most serious obstacle is a desperate shortage of health workers. Yet at the same time, doctors, nurses and pharmacists in English-speaking African countries are emigrating in droves to Britain, the United States, Canada and Australia. In Ghana and Zimbabwe, three-quarters of all doctors emigrate within a few years of completing medical school. Randall Tobias, President Bush's global AIDS coordinator, said in a recent speech that there were more Ethiopian-trained doctors practicing in Chicago than in Ethiopia. 
 The problem isn't new, particularly when it comes to African doctors, but as Celia Dugger wrote recently in The Times, the flight of nurses is a growing phenomenon, fueled principally by the nursing shortages in wealthy nations. Instead of paying salaries that would attract homegrown nurses, American hospitals recruit in the Caribbean, the Philippines, India and Africa. The same is true in Britain. From 1994 to 2001, the number of nurses registering to work in Britain who came from outside Europe grew to 15,000 from 2,000. 
 The group Physicians for Human Rights recently published a detailed report about this problem and its consequences. One is that the world's poorest countries are providing enormous quantities of medical aid to the richest. The United Nations estimates that every time Malawi educates a doctor who practices in Britain, it saves Britain $184,000. 
 It's understandable why overseas work is attractive. AIDS and tuberculosis have stretched African health services to the breaking point, placing impossible demands on nurses in particular. They do their jobs without adequate equipment or drugs. Their paychecks sometimes arrive months late. They risk infection -- in some places, even gloves are scarce. While rich countries average 222 doctors per 100,000 people, Uganda has fewer than 6. Malawi has 17 nurses for every 100,000 citizens; many rich countries have more than 1,000.
 This is a problem with no easy solutions. One of the worst ideas would be any sort of restrictions on emigration, which would not only be discriminatory, but also counterproductive. Africans would be even less likely to choose careers in medicine. Nevertheless, it's unseemly for wealthy countries, which could afford to pay nurses enough to create an ample homegrown supply, to run ads instead to recruit skilled staff in places like South Africa. In 2001, the British National Health Service swore off recruiting nurses from countries without their governments' agreement, but private hospitals and nursing homes still do it. 
 African doctors and nurses understand how much they are needed at home, and many would resist relocation if the conditions under which they work were more bearable. The obvious long-term solution to the medical brain drain is for wealthier countries to reimburse Africa's health and educational systems for the cost of poaching their professionals, and to greatly increase the financing and technical help for Africa's health systems -- in their entirety, not just the clinics that deal with AIDS.
 The concern over AIDS, paradoxically, has created an opportunity by focusing world attention on Africa's miserable health care. Improving it would cost very little money, relatively speaking, and end the exodus of doctors and nurses that is exacerbating the epidemic's devastation.

HEADLINE: Officials Investigate a Qaeda Suspect's Shadowy Life

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER; Heather Timmons contributed reporting for this article.

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 12 

 BODY:
Abu Issa al-Hindi, the operative of Al Qaeda who American officials say is one of 13 men arrested in raids last week in England, has lived a life of subterfuge and survival.
 As an Islamic fighter in the 1990's he took part in a guerrilla campaign against the Indian Army in the rugged and perilous terrain of Kashmir. As an instructor in the Qaeda terrorist indoctrination camps of Afghanistan, he passed on his martial skills to the next generation of volunteers. And as a reconnaissance agent who slipped in and out of the United States in 2000 and 2001, he helped build an archive on the vulnerability of American financial centers on behalf of the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks.
 Much of his history as a reputed Qaeda leader in Britain remains shrouded, but fragments of Mr. Hindi's life as a young man born into a Hindu household in Britain can be pieced together from his own writings, from descriptions attributed to acquaintances and to evidence gathered by the Sept. 11 commission in the United States. 
 Although British officials refuse to confirm the identities of any of the men they arrested last week, citing concerns about prejudicial publicity before they have been charged, American officials say that Mr. Hindi is among the suspects being held at Paddington Green, the high security police station in West London. 
 No photograph has been released of Mr. Hindi, said to be in his mid-30's and about 5 feet 5 inches tall. Not much is known about his parents, presumably immigrants to Britain like millions of other South Asians who came here in the last century to escape political turmoil or improve their circumstances. They have not emerged to speak about their son. 
 According to some reports, Mr. Hindi was one of the young militants who prayed during the 1990's at the Finsbury Park Mosque, which was under the control of Abu Hamza al-Masri, an Egyptian-born extremist who was arrested last month on an extradition warrant from the United States. He is sought there in connection with the 1998 kidnapping of tourists, including two Americans, in Yemen. 
 Mr. Hindi is said to have converted to the Islamic faith at 20 and shortly thereafter, in the early 1990's, went off to fight for the cause of Muslims who opposed Indian rule in divided Kashmir. It was Mr. Hindi's memoir of those years with the mujahedeen, ''The Army of Medinah in Kashmir,'' published by a small Islamic news agency in Birmingham, that first brought him some notice in England's small but growing community of Islamic militants. It may have also attracted the attention of Britain's domestic spy agency, MI5. 
 ''Per chance Muslims are frightened to advance and take the initiative,'' he wrote, ''afraid of being branded as terrorists or deviants, by the people who engineered human destruction themselves -- the enemies of Islam.''
 Mr. Hindi refers to the United States, Britain, France and other Western nations as the great ''interfering'' nations, and he admonishes his followers that ''great stealth is required'' to ''attempt to bring one of these interfering nations to its knees.'' 
 One way of doing so is infiltration from within by people like himself, he said. 
 ''The indigenous believers that reside in these meddling countries'' can be a critical factor because they ''understand the language, culture, area and common practices of the enemy whom they coexist amongst.''
 For British officials, Mr. Hindi's extremism and alienation from British society is an alarming feature within the broader disaffection that British and other European governments now observe among the offspring of South Asian immigrants and immigrants from other Muslim societies. These young European Muslims grow up on soccer, pop music and cricket, but many who come of age feel the strong pull of fundamentalist clerics who preach the glories of struggle against Western conventions and of the ecstasy of martyrdom.
 A major alarm sounded this year when a some young Britons of Pakistani origin were arrested in late March after the police detected their acquisition of a half ton of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, a key ingredient for bomb-making. Police officials say the group was in contact with a Canadian man, also of Pakistani origin, who was teaching them how to make a detonator for a bomb. A criminal case against the group is now pending.
 Mr. Hindi started his career as a holy warrior much earlier and joined the ranks of Al Qaeda before returning home, American officials say. 
 In his memoir from Kashmir, he described the grueling treks with a band of mujahedeen through treacherous mountain terrain and in guerrilla combat against Indian Army forces deployed in camps along the Line of Control in Kashmir. 
 In one passage, he sings the praises of a fellow fighter, who battled hand-to-hand with an Indian soldier until the mujahedeen ''fired a round into the head of the army man'' and ''with his victory complete, beheaded him.''
 As a unseasoned Islamic fighter, Mr. Hindi described how he discovered the rules of warfare the hard way. Marching through exposed valleys subjected the fighters to attack from the surrounding heights. Being trapped by enemy fire raining down from above ''is highly perilous,'' he said, ''and should be avoided at all costs.''
 A preferable mode of operation, he explained, is ''to try and gain the upper hand by being situated over and above the enemy.''
 Using light weapons, including rocket-propelled grenades sometimes filled with chili powder or gasoline to enhance their effect (chili powder creates a ''tear gas'' effect, he wrote; gasoline adds a ''fireball''), the Islamic fighters were little more than a harassing force in the region, Mr. Hindi said.
 He said 85 percent of one mujahedeen faction was wiped out during three years of fighting. He scorned Pakistan's intelligence services , which he said were only too willing to send young Islamic fighters against the Indian Army as a way of ''killing two birds with one stone.''
 After his experiences in Kashmir and the training camps of Afghanistan, Mr. Hindi returned to London. A jacket note from his memoir says he ''now resides in South Thailand, where he emigrated to in 1998, having married there.'' But the biographical material also says that at some point he returned to Afghanistan. 
 That is where American officials believe he came into contact with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who was engaged in planning the Sept. 11 attacks.
 But the World Trade Center was not the target Mr. Mohammed was studying, according to the Sept. 11 commission.
 ''He continued to consider other possibilities for terrorist attacks,'' the report states. ''For example, he sent Qaeda operative Eisa al-Britani to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to learn about the jihad in Southeast Asia.'' (Eisa al-Britani is an alias for Mr. Hindi, American officials say)
 At the direction of Osama bin Laden in early 2001, Mr. Hindi was dispatched to the United States ''to case potential economic and 'Jewish' targets in New York City.'' 
 In July, the Pakistani authorities arrested a young computer specialist, Muhammad Naeem Noor Khan. In his possession was a cache of computer disks containing a huge archive of detailed information about the vulnerabilities of America financial centers in New York, New Jersey and Washington. 
 A senior Western official in London said the question that American and British intelligence officials are trying to answer is whether Mr. Hindi's reconnaissance missions of 2001 ended or were handed off to other Qaeda operatives who have yet to be discovered.
