HEADLINE: A Year Later, Lessons From the Blackout

BYLINE: By PETER FOX-PENNER. 
Peter Fox-Penner, a senior official at the Department of Energy from 1993 to 1996, is chairman of the Brattle Group, a consulting firm that advises utilities.

 BODY:
On Aug. 14, 2003, North America experienced the largest electrical blackout ever. An estimated 50 million Americans lost power for some period, with economic losses estimated to have reached $12 billion. Occurring less than two years after the Sept. 11 attacks, the event again pointed out our vulnerability to large, unseen forces. 
 In the wake of the blackout, New Yorkers and the rest of America learned -- to their amazement -- that the rules for maintaining electric reliability are voluntary, with no penalties for violations. This system worked well when the utility industry was heavily regulated, but now it is badly outdated. Last year, 444 violations of these reliability rules were reported, but not one of the violators could be punished or sanctioned. 
 The federal government and industry investigated the causes of the blackout and recommended preventive measures. The report's top recommendation was to make reliability rules mandatory and enforceable -- a change requiring federal legislation.
 One would have thought that all this would galvanize federal action to enact mandatory rules. One would have thought wrong. Instead, the Bush administration insisted on bundling reliability rules into its omnibus energy bill, reasoning that the importance of reliability rules would get the package passed more easily. But the package -- famously derided by Senator John McCain as a bill of ''Hooters and looters'' has languished, and with it, progress on reliability rules.
 As much as it needs new rules, the power industry also needs clear regulatory policies and an end to the discord that has plagued the power investment climate for a decade. Grid owners and operators need fair and effective rules that promote or even require transmission investment. In this area the administration's energy bill not only falls short, it may actually make matters worse. The bill prevents the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from ''standardizing'' its policies, creates federal authority to force the siting of transmission lines, and provides permanent transmission entitlements to existing transmission holders that are guaranteed to be deeply contentious. It also calls for making several major policy rules in an absurdly compressed period of time. In short, the bill sends uncertain and perhaps even contradictory signals about the climate for grid investment. Wall Street is distinctly unimpressed, and that should worry us.
 While federal legislation is stalled, the industry has taken some initiative. The industry's reliability association has pushed to improve the clarity and enforcement of standards and is increasing its audits of member utilities. In its most recent audit from last year's blackout, it took FirstEnergy Corporation to task for a series of operational failures that allowed the blackout to spread across the Northeast and Midwest. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which has no formal jurisdiction, and state regulatory commissions, which do, have both increased their oversight about as much as they can. In New York, the industry has strongly focused on reliability for decades, but it, too, is limited by federal inaction and the difficulties of supplying power to the metropolitcan region, the energy-hungry corner of the state. A recent audit of the New York Independent System Operator, which manages the state's power grid, found that its preparedness for reliability emergencies was well above average. At the same time, however, the operator's own chief executive reported that progress on building new grid capacity for the region was too slow, and that federal reliability rules were his highest priority. 
 The rest of the nation is, if anything, less vigilant than New York. Many utilities have increased their transmission budgets, but the projects are most small or local. After a nationwide review, one energy consultant, Eric Hirst, recently found that the amount of transmission capacity per unit of power generated was expected to decline 11 percent in the coming decade. And this follows a decade in which power demand has grown 2.7 percent a year while transmission grew only about 0.7 percent annually, leaving an estimated $50 billion investment shortfall. Increasing grid capacity is the top concern of utilities worldwide. 
 The issue is not simply building more, it is building smarter. Our electric grid needs a comprehensive redesign led at the federal level. The North American power network -- the world's single largest machine -- was designed and built in bits and pieces to serve a system of local regulated utilities. It is not designed or controlled to facilitate the tenfold growth in power trading that has occurred in the United States in the past decade. Important new grid technologies are being tested and sometimes used, but redesigning and rebuilding the grid will require a coordinated effort with associated financing.
 We can keep the lights on in America and improve the utility sector, but it will take much more than mandatory reliability rules. We need leadership at the federal level, and lots of it, and we need a stable regulatory and investment framework. Legislation will start the marathon, but only a new design and new investment will finish it.

HEADLINE: Oil Could Clog Growth's Motor

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
THE Consumer Price Index was rising at an annual rate of 4.9 percent through the first half of the year, with the energy sector up at a 36 percent annual rate -- the fastest pace since January 1974, at the end of the Arab oil boycott.
 Gasoline prices were rising even faster, at a 68.6 annual rate nationally and 71.2 percent in the New York metropolitan area. 
 Those figures are threatening, especially because the economy could slow further in the future. 
 Federal Reserve policy makers still do not seem overly concerned. Last week, they raised their benchmark short-term interest rate by a quarter point, to 1.5 percent, the second such move since June, as a precaution against rising prices. In their statement, they said the economy appeared ''poised to resume a stronger pace of expansion going forward.'' And, they added, while inflation is ''somewhat elevated this year,'' some of the ''rise in prices seems to reflect transitory factors.''
 Energy price spurts have been even faster in the past. In the six months that ended in March 1974, seasonally adjusted, energy prices were climbing at an annual rate of 57.5 percent. At the time, the overall C.P.I. was rising at an annual rate of 11.8 percent, more than twice the current pace.
 During the crisis in the Persian Gulf in 1990, the six-month annual rate of increase in the C.P.I.'s energy sector jumped to 32.2 percent in November, just after oil hit a peak of $40.42 a barrel in October. The overall C.P.I. was climbing at a rate of 7.3 percent then.
 One big difference between then and now is that the 1973-1974 and 1990 oil spurts came during recessions. In the first quarter of 1974, the gross domestic product was falling at an annual rate of 3.4 percent; the economy was declining at a 3 percent pace in the fourth quarter of 1990.While the economy has slowed recently, it still grew at a 3 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
 Of course, the threat is that the price of oil -- which hit $46.58 on Friday -- will stay around $45 a barrel for some time and slow growth so much that there is no inflationary threat at all. Crude oil was priced above $40 a barrel for only two days in 1990; it has been above $40 for 36 days so far in this cycle. In 1990, oil sold above $35 a barrel for 24 days, compared with 121 this year.
 The C.P.I. for July, which will be released on Tuesday, is likely to rise 0.2 percent, according to Bloomberg. But if the index jumps more than that, investors could be less worried than might be expected. 
 That's because high oil prices may already be slowing economic growth -- and thereby curbing inflation -- more than Fed policy.

HEADLINE: Racino. Get to Know the Word.

BYLINE: By TERRY GOLWAY

DATELINE: OCEANPORT 

 BODY:
ON a gorgeous Sunday at Monmouth Park, in a small room lined with bound horse-racing records from another century, Governor McGreevey was talking about the good old days of the sport of kings. ''There was a golden age of racing in this state,'' the governor said as he announced a plan to bring the Breeder's Cup championships -- one of racing's most prestigious events -- to Monmouth in 2007. ''We want to reclaim that golden age.''
 Several dozen furlongs away, sitting in the track's crowded grandstand, two horse owners, Michael Harrison of Chester and Dr. Alan Furst of Morristown, had their own ideas about reviving the state's racing industry. ''All the components are here for better racing,'' said Dr. Furst, taking his eyes away from his binoculars for a moment. ''It all has to do with purses. Money from other forms of gambling would mean bigger purses.''
 Mr. Harrison, president of the Thoroughbred Breeders Association of New Jersey, was more blunt: ''We should be getting slots, too.'' 
 More than ever, the health of New Jersey's racing industry is inextricably linked to the fortunes of Atlantic City's casinos. These two competitors for the gambling dollar, having eyed each other suspiciously for decades, might well be on the verge of a partnership that could drastically change the racing experience in New Jersey. 
 It all comes down to slot machines, or, to use a government-speak euphemism, video lottery terminals. The racing industry, which accounts for 36,000 jobs in the state, wants them. The casino industry, which employs 45,000 people and spreads millions of dollars around the state each year, has been opposed to them for years. 
 But in a compromise that could change the gambling landscape in New Jersey, Governor McGreevey recently signed legislation giving the state-run Sports and Exposition Authority the power to lease the two tracks it owns, the Meadowlands and Monmouth Park. After years of battling declining crowds, the demise of Garden State Race Track, and a near non-existent calendar at Atlantic City Race Course, the state is ready to get out of the racing business.
 Moreover, George R. Zoffinger, president and chief executive of the Sports and Exposition Authority, confirmed that several casino operators were among the 17 organizations that have already expressed interest in bidding for the tracks. Churchill Downs Inc., which operates the famed track that is home to the Kentucky Derby, and the Magna Entertainment Corporation, which manages Santa Anita in California, Gulfstream Park in Florida and others around the country, are also believed to be interested in leasing the two New Jersey tracks. 
 Mr. Zoffinger, citing confidentiality agreements, declined to identify the interested casino companies, but he said he expected the industry ''to take a hard look at whether or not they want to be the operators of the tracks.''
 ''I can tell you that there will be aggressive bids for our properties from the casinos,'' he said. ''If they decide to do that, slot machines will not be far behind, and that will keep the racing business competitive.''
 Throughout the country -- and particularly in the states bordering New Jersey -- racetracks are eagerly converting their poorly attended facilities to mini-casinos, known popularly as racinos, by offering slot machines as well as pari-mutuel wagering. The increase in revenue has meant bigger purses, quality fields and a more prosperous industry. But in New Jersey, horse racing's salvation has for years been considered Atlantic City's nightmare.
 To help stave off competition from the tracks, the casino operators recently agreed to give $86 million over the next four years to racing industry to increase purses -- the money at stake in each race -- at Monmouth, the Meadowlands and Freehold Raceway, in an effort to attract more and better horses. In return, the state said it would not pursue racetrack slot machines for the time being.
 But the future may not be put off so easily. Pressure from New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware, where video slots are up and running or on the way, has made it all the more likely that the machines will find a place in New Jersey. So even as the state celebrated a weekend of well-attended championship events, from harness-racing's Hambletonian at the Meadowlands on Aug. 7 to the running of the Haskell Invitational Handicap at Monmouth Park the following afternoon, drastic change was the odds-on favorite among the sport's enthusiasts. 
 ''We're at a critical juncture,'' said Mr. Harrison as he looked out on the 45,000 fans -- far larger than the usual crowd -- gathered to watch the Haskell. ''We have to find a way to compete.''
 But bringing slot machines to the track may require more than just a marriage between two formerly hostile and suspicious industries. State Senator Paul A. Sarlo, a Bergen County Democrat and supporter of video slot machines at the tracks, said he and other lawmakers believed such a move would require a voter-approved constitutional amendment because casino gambling outside of Atlantic City is currently illegal. 
 It seems like one of those rarities in the gambling world: a win-win situation. The state's horse owners and breeders would get the slots they say they need to compete with the neighboring states, and the casinos would have a chance to get in on the action instead of spending time, money and energy fighting a defensive battle. 
 If the casinos, either individually or collectively, do make an aggressive bid to run the two tracks, it will mark a drastic turn of events for both industries in New Jersey. After all, those who long for the return of what the governor called the ''golden age'' of racing -- when the Meadowlands routinely drew crowds of more than 20,000 in the late 1970's -- blame casinos for today's meager crowds of 6,000 or 7,000.
 For their part, however, casino operators have trouble hiding their disinterest in racing's troubles, viewing the sport as a dying enterprise dependent on subsidies from competitors. And in New Jersey, the rivalry between the two industries has neatly coincided with the state's traditional north-south hostilities, with each side quick to take offense over some real or imagined slight. Simply put, some see it as a rivalry between the Meadowlands in Bergen County and the casinos in Atlantic City.
 Yet these days, all is moonlight and magnolias for these once-hardy antagonists.
 ''There's a lot of interaction between the casino and racing industry,'' said State Senator William L. Gormley, an Atlantic County Republican with close ties to the casinos. ''There's a lot of good will being built up. Everybody's saying that.''
 Explaining the recent embrace, Mr. Zoffinger said it was a relationship born out of necessity. ''People's eyes have been opened because they know they have to compete with New York and Pennsylvania,'' he said.
 This entente cordiale would find its ultimate expression in an outright partnership between the racing industry and the casinos. In this courtship, the racing industry is very much the pursuer, and the casinos are playing the role of the not-particularly-distant love interest. Racing organizations like the New Jersey Horsemen's Association have signaled a desire to consummate this once-unlikely pairing. And the casinos have not rejected their advances. 
 ''We're looking at all the possibilities,'' said Lawrence Mullin, executive vice president of Atlantic City's newest casino, the Borgata.
 Noting that the Borgata's parent company, Boyd Gaming, recently took over Delta Downs racetrack in Louisiana, Mr. Mullin said the company ''would be very interested to explore'' a partnership with New Jersey's racing industry. 
 As he put it, these days racetrack casinos are the gambling industry's equivalent of convenience markets. ''They don't put the large retailers out of business,'' he said. ''The successful ones grow their market.''
 Senator Sarlo, believes that privatizing the two tracks and allowing video slots at only the Meadowlands -- but not at Monmouth Park or Freehold, which are closer to Atlantic City -- would bring in nearly a billion dollars a year. 
 ''We're talking about a major-league source of newfound revenue, which could go toward property tax reform and local economic development while also offsetting any losses the casinos might envision,'' said Senator Sarlo, who sponsored the privatization bill that the governor signed at Monmouth Park on Aug. 8.
 The leases, if approved, are expected to bring in at least $250 million to the state, Mr. Zoffinger said, while the Meadowlands and Monmouth Park bring in only about $23 million a year right now. ''We'll be getting a good feel for the price these two assets can garner in the open market pretty soon,'' Mr. Zoffinger said, adding that the 17 potential operators received information from the authority in the last three weeks. 
 ''The question will be: Is anybody offering an adequate enough price for us to get out of the business and hand it over to the private sector?'' he said.
 That may be Mr. Zoffinger's question. But Michael Pollock, publisher of the Gaming Industry Observer, a trade journal, has one of his own. Mr. Pollock wonders if the state has thought out all the implications of creating what he called ''in-state competition'' for Atlantic City. 
 ''You have billions of dollars invested in Atlantic City under the state constitutional premise that gaming would be limited to Atlantic City,'' he said. ''This creates a very difficult situation if you bring in VLT's. Now you're undercutting the long-standing view that New Jersey offers a favorable regulatory and investment climate. It adds a level of risk, and that by definition would add to the cost of capital for any New Jersey casino operator.''
 Which is why Senator Gormley, while waxing eloquent on the subject of newfound harmony between the tracks and the casinos, is not quite ready for what such a pairing would inevitably produce. ''We are on the verge of a building boom in Atlantic City that will create 10,000 new jobs,'' he said, ''so VLT's can be looked at down the road, but not right now.''
 But even that counts as something of a concession. For years, the casino industry tried to make sure that if video slots were down the road, they would never make it past cleverly placed legislative and regulatory obstacles. As recently as several months ago, the casino industry asserted that the slots would lead to the loss of 12,000 jobs in Atlantic City and nearly $500 million in revenue. But those obstacles are being worn down by relentless inevitability. With the passage of legislation last year allowing video slots in New York and this year in Pennsylvania, explained Mr. Harrison, the horse owner and president of the breeder's organization, New Jersey has to respond.
 ''When there are slot machines in Pennsylvania and New York, people will go where it is more convenient,'' Mr. Harrison said. ''I think the casino industry may be starting to understand that.''
 The racing industry, by contrast, has been ready to embrace the new world of multiple gambling options for some time. While horse racing can be as reverent about its past as baseball and golf, many of its enthusiasts, from bettors to owners, see no reason to bemoan the creeping conversion of tracks into multi-purpose gambling halls. 
 Standing on the rail at the Meadowlands last Saturday as a crowd of about 30,000 -- more than triple a typical night's attendance -- awaited the Hambletonian, Roland Carey of New Brunswick said he would welcome slot machines at the track. A self-described regular who was even more regular 20 years ago, when he went to the track every day, Mr. Carey said he believed slots at the track would benefit ''the whole state'' and wouldn't ''take away from Atlantic City.''
 ''The people who come here don't want to go down there,'' he said.
 If the 46-year-old Mr. Carey seemed sanguine, it was understandable. He had just hit an exacta by playing his age -- he picked the four horse to win, and the six horse to come in second. ''That's how you do it,'' he said. ''Pick one number and stick with it.''
 Sitting on a grassy knoll near the finish line, Elysia Pawlowicz of Harrison and Felicia Kulig of Union City were entertaining Ms. Kulig's 24-year-old brother Chris, who was visiting from Massachusetts. ''We just wanted to do something different,'' Ms. Kulig said.
 They and the thousands of young people who trooped to Monmouth the next day for the Haskell offered a glimpse of what Dr. Furst said might have been. ''We lost a generation by not properly promoting the sport,'' said Dr. Furst, who recently opened a practice in Denville. Mr. Harrison, sitting behind Dr. Furst and his wife, Amy, agreed. 
 ''Look at the way people followed Smarty Jones,'' he said, referring to the winner of this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness. ''I was at a basketball game and people in the stands stopped watching their daughters and went to find a television so they could watch Smarty Jones.'' 
 But even without a superstar attraction like Smarty Jones, a weekend of high-profile racing at the Meadowlands and at Monmouth Park offered a glimpse of Governor McGreevey's lost golden age of racing. When Rainbow Blue, the overwhelming favorite in Saturday's sixth race at the Meadowlands, broke stride at the quarter-mile pole, the collective groan might have been heard in the casinos of Atlantic City. And the cooler-wielding, burger-grilling, midriff-showing crowd at Monmouth on Sunday resembled nothing if not the state's largest beach party. 
 Yet that was only one day, and track veterans like Mr. Harrison and Dr. Furst know that last weekend was an illusion. The state racing calendar is much shorter than it used to be -- 120 dates for thoroughbreds, compared with more than 300 two decades ago. Garden State Race Track is gone and forgotten. Atlantic City Race Course runs about 10 live cards a year, and exists mainly to provide betting on out-of-town races. Freehold struggles to hang on. And even though the Meadowlands and Monmouth draw well, it is not like the days when 20,000 regularly showed up. The horse racing industry, from the tracks to the state's shrinking number of horse farms, is at a turning point, Mr. Harrison said. 
 ''This year, for example, we have only 300 thoroughbred foals in New Jersey,'' he said. ''We had about 1,400 a dozen years ago.''
 The fact is, breeders have gone elsewhere in search of more lucrative purses.
 For now, racing fans hope that slot machines will bring back breeders and fans, and perhaps even a long-gone golden age.

HEADLINE: Extremists and Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD GOLDBERG. 
Richard Goldberg is president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New Jersey.

 BODY:
AS the father of an 11-month-old, I have the usual parental concerns about his future: that he has clean water to drink, clean air to breathe and a good job that gives him the ability to pay the bills and still enjoy a quality lifestyle. 
 In the last couple of years, environmental activists have had a windfall of victories, mainly as a result of aggressive targeting of businesses by the state Department of Environmental Protection. Prime examples were unjustified raids on hundreds of law-abiding companies in our cities and the hiring of an out-of-state bounty-hunting law firm to go after New Jersey companies for natural resource damages.
 Most recently, the governor signed the Highlands preservation legislation last week, restricting development in much of northwestern New Jersey. This takes decision-making abilities away from local municipalities and places it in the hands of a politically appointed commission. Many companies in fields like construction, engineering, plumbing, electrical, roofing and paving put up a valiant fight as they watched their ability to earn a living restricted to only some areas of the state 
 Many of these policies will also contribute to housing shortages, driving up the prices of existing homes and putting home ownership out of reach for more middle- and lower-middle-class New Jerseyans. 
 These antigrowth policies, advocated by environmentalists, also have a direct impact on your property taxes. While overall state spending continues to increase year after year, state aid to municipalities fails to keep pace with rising costs. As a result, inadequate state financing triggers record property-tax increases at the local level, causing many people to struggle to simply keep their homes.
 One of the few ways municipalities can relieve the burden on the homeowner is to attract companies and businesses that pay taxes and fees and infuse money into local economies by employing local residents.
 After all the restrictions on development, Governor McGreevey, with the support of many employers, unions and average taxpayers, put forth a ''smart growth'' bill that would ease the burdensome development restrictions and expedite permits and approvals in the urban and suburban areas targeted for growth. We are not talking about building in the Pinelands or in other environmentally sensitive areas; we are talking about revitalizing cities like Paterson, Hackensack, Newark and Camden and surrounding areas that would benefit from the economic stimulus redevelopment brings. Nobody would be against revitalizing our cities, right? Wrong!
 Environmental activists-turned-extremists labeled the governor a traitor for signing that bill. They were not satisfied with reducing development in most of the state. Nor were they satisfied with increased enforcement and penalties or with the sweeping protections to the water supply of the Highlands. They want all development in New Jersey stopped. They were even angered by the appointment of the state community affairs commissioner, Susan Bass Levin, as the state's ''smart growth'' ombudsman. As a former mayor, Ms. Levin knows that there has to be a balance to give municipalities the ability to develop and attract ratables, while protecting open space. She will cut bureaucratic red tape when it benefits all involved. This is good for New Jersey. 
 Unfortunately, the environmental extremists have made this an all-or-nothing fight. It is time we expose them for what they are and oppose their positions that have a negative impact on the people of New Jersey. 
 We elect representatives to make decisions on our behalf. We need to ensure that they have the ability to work with business for responsible development that will have a positive impact on our property taxes. Our taxes are too high. If we continue to rely only on suburban homeowners to pay property taxes, while leaving our cities to fend for themselves, New Jerseyans will not be able to afford the limited housing that is left. If the developers and builders find their work diminished, thousands will be off the payroll, with many going on public assistance or being forced to abandon the state. 
 There may be a bit of light at the end of the tunnel. As a result of a lawsuit initiated by the building community, the state Supreme Court recently overturned state regulations that had halted residential construction near freshwater wetlands. In its unanimous ruling, the court referred to the Department of Environmental Protection as ''overzealous'' and said it had ''overstepped its bounds.'' It is now time for the Legislature to provide true oversight of that department and to ensure that a balance can be found. Legislators have to stop pacifying extremists or the voters might start branding them ''extreme'' when they come up for re-election.
 As a voice for the business community, as well as a father looking out for his son's future, I will continue to support smart growth, economic expansion and the cutting of unnecessary regulatory red tape. I can do this while supporting smart policies that ensure clean air and water. This kind of balance will create jobs, and that is what most mainstream taxpayers want and need. It is the only way to keep New Jersey an affordable place to live, work and raise a family and, at the same time, give families an ever increasing quality of life.

HEADLINE: Near Outlets and Marshes: New Condos

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

DATELINE: SECAUCUS 

 BODY:
IT may seem like stale news: another riverfront condominium project going up in New Jersey directly west of Manhattan. But here's the kicker: it's not the Gold Coast, and it's not the Hudson. It's Secaucus, the city of outlets, and it's the Hackensack, a river best known for its marshes and wetlands.
 Riverside Court, a 212-unit development under construction now by Baker Residential, will be the first large-scale condo complex to open in almost 20 years in Secaucus, which has a population of only 15,000. 
 In the mid to late 1980's, four condo communities -- all part of the huge Harbor Cove development -- transformed this sleepy burg in the New Jersey Meadowlands, spurred expansion in the retail outlet district and the downtown area, and began to attract corporate offices.
 In the last decade, Secaucus became something of a media hub. Both MSNBC and Channel 9 have studios here, and a number of other networks maintain news bureaus in town.
 A crucial part of the town's appeal to both businesses and residents, certainly, is its location -- a mere five miles from Times Square. Midtown is a quick commute by car or express bus on Route 3 to the Lincoln Tunnel. The New Jersey Turnpike also cuts through town, and both it and Route 3 connect to the Garden State Parkway, providing easy commutes to Newark and other employment centers west of the Hudson.
 The 15.2-acre Riverside Court site is just north of Route 3, immediately off the Meadowlands Parkway exit, and within view of the turnpike overpass.
 The site, sandwiched between the Hackensack River and a neighborhood of single-family homes with a few apartment buildings on its fringes, will be gated, said Clark Atwood, a vice president of Baker Residential.
 The complex will feature a riverside pool and cabana, Mr. Atwood said. ''We're also building a river walk along the Hackensack,'' he added. ''There is a public boat ramp nearby, and you can take canoe and kayak tours of the river and the Meadowlands marshes.''
 He described the Secaucus site as presenting ''an unusual opportunity to buy a home in an urban area that also offers the amenities of nature.'' Secaucus does possess some yin and yang qualities in that regard. For example, the local Stop & Shop supermarket is just down the road from the Riverside site, and next door to it is the entrance to the Mill Creek Marsh Trail -- a prime vista for bird watchers.
 The Meadowlands sports complex, with Giants Stadium and Continental Airlines Arena, is just across the Hackensack River. Site preparation work has begun on open acres around the arena to build Xanadu, a major entertainment-retail-office complex that could enliven the entire Meadowlands area economically. 
 Meanwhile, Secaucus retains distinctly suburban features. There is an ice rink, a roller hockey rink, a soccer field, a volunteer fire department, a Shade Tree Commission and a local theater troupe. There are eight churches and a Hindu temple.
 PRICES for the two-bedroom town-house-style condominiums at the Riverside Court development will start in the mid-$400,000's and go up to $600,000. Mr. Atwood said that Baker was positioning the community as a convenient alternative to New Jersey's ''Gold Coast'' towns that front on the Hudson across from Manhattan.
 While Hoboken is in the midst of major redevelopment, he observed, many other riverfront towns do not have enough open land left to support construction of hundreds of new units as Baker is doing in Secaucus.
 Riverside Court is designed to reflect ''the values and traditions of an era gone by,'' Mr. Atwood said.
 The exterior of the attached three-story town house buildings is modeled after classic 19th-century brownstones, with bay windows, arched entryways, Juliet balconies and French doors.
 Buyers have a choice of four layouts, offering 1,800 to 2,400 square feet of space. A third of the units were sold during the design and site preparation phases, according to the developer.
 The company opened two model homes at the beginning of the month for tours by prospective buyers.
 The condos at the complex will each have one- or two-car garages, fireplaces, hardwood floors in the foyers, formal dining rooms, eat-in kitchens with granite countertops, and master bedroom suites with cathedral ceilings, sitting rooms and baths with soaking tubs.
 ''There is just a dearth of product like this out there,'' Mr. Atwood said.
 The state's new Highlands Preservation Act, prohibiting construction on a wide swath of suburban acreage deemed critical to open space and fresh water initiatives, and the McGreevey administration's strict focus on urban redevelopment, have put several large residential projects ''on hold forever,'' the developer observed.
 ''Developers have been forced to go closer in to the cities,'' he said. ''Here that has worked out great for us and great for buyers. We took a piece of property that wasn't doing anything and turned it into a place where people can work and live.''
 Mr. Atwood said the first closings on homes at Riverside Court would take place next month. Construction will continue at the complex, however, through mid-2006.

HEADLINE: An Escape Clause on Preferential Rents

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
STURGIS WARNER'S rent is tripling.
 Not that Mr. Warner hasn't had, in his own estimation, ''a sweetheart deal'' for years -- $530 a month for a one-bedroom apartment in a Greek-columned building on Lafayette Street in NoHo.
 ''But still, it's tripling!'' Mr. Warner, 54, said of the jump to $1,549 called for in the new lease for his rent-stabilized apartment. And, based on the on-off income of an Off Broadway theater director, Mr. Warner doesn't know whether he will have to move. ''Frankly, it's not easy being a theater artist with the real estate situation in Manhattan,'' he said. 
 Mr. Warner and thousands of other tenants are being jolted by a change in the rent-stabilization law regarding what are called preferential rents -- rents lower than what the landlord could have legally charged.
 Before June 15, 2003, if a landlord signed a lease granting a preferential rent, all subsequent increases were based on that preferential rent, not on the higher legal rent the owner could have originally charged. Upon vacancy, a new tenant could be charged the legal rent, including any increases based on the legal rent that could have been added during the preferred tenant's occupancy.
 Last year, however, the Legislature amended Section 26-511 of the New York City Rent Stabilization Law, providing that when the lease for an apartment with a preferential rent is renewed, the owner can jump to the legal rent even if the preferred tenant is staying in place.
 Precisely how many people are facing such big jumps could not be determined. Owners of regulated apartments must annually record their rents with the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. According to housing division statistics, 11 percent of the approximately 860,000 apartments registered last year had preferential rents. But because of the nature of many preferential rents -- often the landlord wants to keep a friend, a relative or simply an obliging tenant in place -- not all preferred tenants face increases.
 Market conditions, of course, are the primary impetus for increases. ''With the reduction in crime, city investments in housing rehabilitation and the population increase, there's now rent pressure in virtually every neighborhood,'' said Michael H. Schill, director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. ''Many neighborhoods now attract renters who 5, 10 years ago wouldn't have considered them, places like East New York, Red Hook.''
 Frank Ricci, a spokesman for the Rent Stabilization Association, a major landlord group, thinks the new law ''is good for owners and tenants.''
 ''Under the old rules,'' Mr. Ricci said, ''many owners didn't grant preferential rents because they would be locked in. Now, if they know they can do a preferential rent and adjust at the end of the lease, they're going to be more flexible.''
 But Andrew Scherer, author of ''Residential Landlord-Tenant Law in New York'' (West Group, 2001), said: ''The difference between legal and preferential rent can be hundreds of dollars. The jump can be too high and the tenant could be displaced.''
 Mr. Ricci countered: ''Look, they got a benefit for however long. I don't think there's anything wrong with going to the legal rent.''
 The new law has become ''fodder for litigation,'' Mr. Scherer said.
 Geoffrey Doig-Marx has lived in a Hell's Kitchen walk-up for 12 years. He received a preferential rent of $635 ''because it was so bad around here back then.''
 ''Now it's Upper Chelsea; that's my definition,'' he said.
 By last October, Mr. Doig-Marx's preferred rent had climbed to $946. Then he received a notice, from a new landlord, that his rent would rise to $1,385, because of the new law. When he refused to pay, pointing to a specific clause in his original lease granting him a preferential rent for the duration of his tenancy, Mr. Doig-Marx received an eviction notice.
 His lawyer, Lynn Armentrout, argued, ''The state doesn't have the power to undo or substantially impair a private contract.'' Two months ago, the Housing Court judge, Anthony J. Fiorella Jr., ruled in Mr. Doig-Marx's favor. 
 By far, however, most preferred tenants don't have such specific stipulations in their leases. And in Mr. Scherer's opinion, the new law needs clarification. ''It clearly applies to preferential rent in leases signed since its passage,'' he said, ''but it is not clear about its application to preferential rents agreed to prior to its enactment.''

SECTION: Section 11; Column 4; Real Estate Desk; STREETSCAPES/Philip Gengembre Hubert; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1211 words

HEADLINE: The 19th-Century Innovator Who Invented the Co-op

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
TODAY'S co-op prices seem to have no end -- so where, exactly was the beginning? One woman, Cornelia Frohman Santomenna, has been developing a trove of information on the work of her great-grandfather, Philip Gengembre Hubert, who invented the co-op apartment. Although he never saw riches, Hubert's revolution in housing has become a highly profitable mainstay in the New York housing market. 
 Born in France in 1830 with the unwieldy surname of Gengembre, Mrs. Santomenna's great-grandfather took his mother's simpler family name, Hubert, when he arrived in the United States in 1849. Family stories and some printed sources say that during the Civil War Hubert sold the United States government the rights to his invention of a ''self-fastening button'' for $120,000. He also worked as a French teacher and, when he came to New York in 1865, as an architect. 
 He linked up with the architect James Pirsson, and Hubert & Pirsson had a respectable business designing smaller buildings, including what is now the picturesque little Church of St. Thomas More, built in 1870 at 65 East 89th Street, in the neo-Gothic style. 
 The field of apartment-house design was in ferment in post-Civil War New York, and soon buildings like the Dakota, at 72nd and Central Park West, evidenced a new vision of the upper-class multiple dwelling. But Hubert added something different to the mix -- co-op ownership. 
 In 1880, with his help, a syndicate of artists began putting up the Rembrandt, a building of studios and apartments at 152 West 57th Street -- demolished around 1970 and now the site of Carnegie Hall Tower. Hubert and Pirsson were its architects, and the building application rendered the name of the owner as ''Hubert Home Club.'' 
 The six-story Rembrandt was completed in 1881, with 11-room apartments for each of the eight shareholders, and extra rental units. An article in The New York Tribune in 1881 said that the yearly cost per shareholder was $1,250 (half for maintenance and taxes, half for the $100,000 mortgage to buy the land and erect the building), less $800 per member for the rental income from the other units, leaving the total yearly cost at $450 per shareholder. There was no reference to an initial fee.
 Since comparable apartments rented for $1,000 and up yearly, this calculation caught people's attention -- especially after shares in the Rembrandt sold for a substantial increase over their original cost before construction was over. 
 What started as a one-time solution for agreeable artists' housing quickly evolved into a professional undertaking, as Hubert began organizing other Home Clubs. 
 A brochure of 1881 noted that shareholders could protect themselves against ''uncongenial neighbors'' and also remarked that the startling economies of the Home Clubs were based on the shareholders' willingness to avoid showy decorations, large common areas, large rooms and pretentious addresses. 
 Hubert's brochure also disavowed any ''socialistic'' overtones, but the early co-op movement clearly resonated with wider discussions of how Marxist theory might be applied to urban life in the industrial era, discussions that were then in the air. 
 But when Hubert became a developer, instead of just an architect-adviser, the game changed. A developer's logic is always ''more,'' whereas a tenant-builder's goal is simply ''enough.'' Hubert promoted half a dozen more Home Clubs within two years -- of which only the Chelsea Hotel at 222 West 23rd Street and the apartment building at 121 Madison Avenue, at 30th Street, survive -- and other developers also jumped on board the co-op locomotive.
 One of these was Jose de Navarro, a Spanish-born financier who bought a gigantic plot, 200 by 425 feet, facing Central Park South east of Seventh Avenue and reaching back to West 58th Street. On these he began erecting, in 1882, the eight buildings known as the Madrid, the Cordova, the Granada, the Valencia, the Lisbon, the Barcelona, the Saragossa and the Tolosa -- collectively, the Navarro Flats, for which Hubert was the architect. 
 The 10-story buildings had expansive apartments, typically with six bedrooms, and a parlor, living room, dining room and library. These sold for $15,000 to $20,000, with annual maintenance charges of $1,000 to $2,000. 
 But even before the 128-unit Navarro Flats was finished, red flags were going up: in 1883, The New York Tribune advised buyers to routinely ''double the estimates given'' for construction and operation. Such downbeat talk continued as the co-op bubble began to deflate, especially after the Navarro Flats sank into foreclosure, the victim of legal problems and poor cost control.
 The Real Estate Record and Guide took a swipe at Hubert in a discussion of co-ops by noting that ''there are some architects all of whose buildings have cost more than the estimates.'' More restrictive construction laws and the spectacular failure of the Navarro Flats -- where some of the original shareholders lost all their equity, and the complex was completed as rentals -- was the frost that killed off New York's early co-op bloom, a flower that did not blossom again until after 1900. 
 Hubert continued with his architectural practice -- he and Pirsson did the charming little group of row houses at 146-56 East 89th Street in 1886 -- but his prescient co-op idea seemed to be a pipe dream. It appears Hubert lived in the Chelsea for a year or two, and in 1890 he designed, built and lived in the Sevillia apartment building at 117 West 58th Street, which he kept as an investment. It is a handsome, vigorous structure, elegant Renaissance rather than the picturesque Queen Anne of almost all the early co-ops -- but the Sevillia was a rental. 
 Of Hubert's personal life we know little that would give us a clue to his unusual housing invention. His father was also an architect, and Philip Hubert spoke English with a French accent. He avoided alcohol, preferred vegetarian cooking and never used tobacco. He was a painter, writer and literary and drama critic.
 His great-granddaughter, Mrs. Santomenna, says she has manuscripts for several plays he wrote, including ''False Charms'' of 1882. She also has detailed construction cost schedules for the Sevillia, correspondence to and from Hubert, drawings and sketches she thinks are Hubert's of the French countryside, and numerous patent documents in his name, covering plastering techniques, fireproofing and plumbing. 
 Hubert left New York in the 1890's for California and built a house for himself there, with a room called Little Egypt, with a false window looking out onto an electrically illuminated desert landscape. He died there in 1911; Mrs. Santomenna says he was financially comfortable, but not rich. 
 But of what model he used, what inspiration he saw, in developing the co-op idea in New York, he left no record, only the institution of the ''Home Club,'' one that is now so prevalent in the landscape of New York housing.

The robust seventh-floor balcony ironwork on the Sevillia (building below). The building was designed and lived in by the architect Philip Gengembre Hubert (inset, with grandson).

HEADLINE: Athletes Slow Down More Slowly

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT. 
E-mail: keepingscore@nytimes.com

 BODY:
They are old enough to remember the United States' boycott of the 1980 Moscow Olympics. Their careers started before Courtney McCool, a gymnast whose name you will soon know, was born. And they do not need to hear that they are an inspiration simply by making this year's Olympics, thank you. 
 They are all serious medal contenders, and there are now enough of them to talk about as if they were their own unofficial Olympic team. They make up the great nation of 30-something. 
 Gail Devers, 37, will try to add to the gold medals she won in 1992 and 1996 when she runs the 100 meters this week and the 100 hurdles next week. Akakios Kakiasvili, 35, will try to thrill his fellow Greeks by winning a fourth consecutive gold in weight lifting. Aleksandr Popov, a 32-year-old Russian, will again vie for the title of the world's fastest swimmer. Jeannie Longo-Ciprelli of France -- who at 45 is an honorary member of team 30-something -- will climb onto her bike for a sixth consecutive Summer Games. 
 The aging of the Olympic athlete has gone largely unnoticed by most fans, shrouded by the influx of fresh faces at each Games. Teenagers are again likely to dominate much of the discussion, with the 16-year-old McCool, the swimmer Michael Phelps, 19, and the sprinter Allyson Felix, 18, all candidates for stardom.
 On the medal stand, though, teenagers are increasingly the exception. The winners in almost every major sport -- cycling, rowing, swimming, track and field, volleyball -- and many minors ones -- archery, kayaking, handball, table tennis -- have become older during the last three decades. Gymnasts, seemingly the ultimate symbol of Olympic youth, became younger in the 1970's and 80's, but have aged somewhat in the last decade.
 At the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, teenagers and the 30-and-older crowd earned 10 medals each in track and field. Four years ago, in Sydney, Australia, the oldsters beat the teenagers in a rout in the track and field events, 46 medals to 4.
 The shift has helped to alter athletes' and scientists' understanding of when the human body peaks. For years, people assumed that the early- and mid-20's marked the last time athletes could run their fastest or jump their highest. It was a sensible assumption, because that was the age of the world's champions.
 But it now looks as if the reason was more economic than biological. Before the Olympics allowed professionals to compete, athletes had to retire, or curtail their training, and find jobs before they turned 30. They were quickly replaced in the winner's circle by younger athletes practicing full time. 
 ''What we thought was aging,'' said Joel M. Stager, a professor of kinesiology at Indiana University, ''was really just inactivity.''
 Today, endorsement contracts with clothing and equipment companies like Speedo allow athletes to continue competing long after college. The deals often pay $25,000 a year or less, but it can be enough. For athletes from poor countries, like the runners from Kenya, saving even a small amount of the pay can make them wealthy when they do eventually retire and return home. 
 ''It's a completely different ballgame when you can make a living,'' said Rowdy Gaines, a former world-record holder and winner of three gold medals at the 1984 Los Angeles Games in swimming. He is now a commentator for NBC Sports. ''It keeps you in the sport much longer.''
 A virtuous cycle is then formed: athletes keep competing because they can and because they have new hope of winning as they age. Advances in training, reducing injury risks and teaching athletes how to eliminate tiny inefficiencies in their technique allow some to continue even as they reach beyond 30-something.
 Merlene Ottey, 44, not only remembers the Moscow Games, but also competed in them for Jamaica, winning bronze in the 200 meters; it was her first of eight Olympic medals. She may no longer be a threat to win, but she will be sprinting again this year, as a naturalized citizen of Slovenia. Martina Navratilova, a tennis star for almost 30 years, has a chance to win a medal for the United States in doubles at age 47.
 On reflection, perhaps this all should have become obvious much earlier than it did. In 1940, a 22-year-old American named Barney Ewell was probably the world's fastest man, but World War II canceled the Games that year and again in 1944. After serving in the United States Army, Ewell shocked fans by qualifying for the 1948 London Games and, at age 30, winning two silvers and a gold as a sprinter. This newspaper called him Ol' Barney.
 All these years later, noted Dave Johnson, director of the Penn Relays, Ewell looks less like an exception and more like a once-rare example of an athlete allowed to keep running into the twilight of his prime.
 The lesson for all of us who will be spending much of the next two weeks in front of the television seems clear enough. Grab a ball or throw on some sneakers sometime soon, and stop moaning about being too old.

HEADLINE: Fans Converge to Send Off Smarty Jones

BYLINE: By BILL FINLEY

DATELINE: BENSALEM, Pa., Aug. 14 

 BODY:
A loss in the Belmont Stakes and the announcement that he had been retired have done little to diminish the enthusiasm of Smarty Jones's legion of fans. About 10,000 of them turned out Saturday at Philadelphia Park to say farewell to the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes.
 Smarty Jones will be taken by van Sunday evening to Three Chimneys Farm in Midway, Ky., where he will stand at stud. It was announced Aug. 2 that Smarty Jones, who has sustained bone bruises in the area of all four cannon bones, would not race again. 
 Although Smarty Jones raced just twice at Philadelphia Park and had not started there since Nov. 22, the track in suburban Philadelphia was very much his home. He was stabled there throughout much of his nine-race career, and many Philadelphia fans regarded him a local hero.
 ''It's been a wonderful experience,'' said Lynne Koach, who was wearing a Smarty Jones T-shirt and button. ''He's been good for this state, this city, even this country. I feel really sad today, because I'll miss him so much. Besides, he's cute.''
 After the third race, Smarty Jones, led by the exercise rider Pete Van Trump and the groom Mario Arriaga, walked the length of the stretch, took a few turns in the paddock and entered the winner's circle for the conclusion of the brief ceremony. Smarty Jones was accompanied by an entourage that included the trainer John Servis. Roy and Pat Chapman, the horse's co-owners, did not attend.
 ''I want to thank the Chapmans for giving me an opportunity to train the greatest horse to come from Pennsylvania and maybe the greatest horse of all time,'' Servis said, his words greeted by a loud cheer. ''He gave us a great ride. We're doing what's in the best interests of him. That's the way we have to look at it. I know you guys had a lot of fun, but nobody had more fun with this than myself and my family. We had to look out for the horse. I can tell you we're going to miss him.''
 After losing in the Belmont Stakes, his only career defeat, Smarty Jones was expected to run at Philadelphia Park in the Pennsylvania Derby, at either the Meadowlands or Monmouth in the Pegasus, then in the Breeders' Cup Classic at Lone Star Park. The Chapmans had also maintained that they were interested in bring the horse back as a 4-year-old.
 The injury would not have prevented Smarty Jones from running as a 4-year-old. Economic factors may have played the most significant role in his retirement. When an agreement was reached with Three Chimneys that placed Smarty Jones's value as a stallion at $39 million, he became worth far more as a sire than as a racehorse. 
 But most fans attending the retirement party seemed to be in a forgiving mood.
 ''My feeling is that if he ever got hurt or had to be put down, I'd be devastated,'' Harry Beccari said. ''I'd rather have him ride off into the sunset like this and lead a great life for a long time to come.''

Speightstown Impresses
 (By The New York Times), SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Better Talk Now, at odds of better than 7 to 1, was the upset winner of the Grade I Sword Dancer Invitational on Saturday at Saratoga Race Course.
 But it was Speightstown's victory in the Grade II Alfred G. Vanderbilt Handicap that was the most impressive performance of the day.
 Ridden by John Velazquez and trained by Todd Pletcher, Speightstown covered six furlongs in 1 minute 8.04 seconds to equal a track record, set by Spanish Riddle in 1972. Speightstown carried 120 pounds in winning his fourth consecutive race and solidified his credentials as one of the top sprinters in training, alongside Pico Central, who is slated to run at Del Mar on Sunday.
 ''He's just so good right now, it's scary,'' Pletcher said after Speightstown blazed an opening quarter mile in 22.05 seconds and a half in 44.40, all while dueling with Mike's Classic. After pulling away by the top of the stretch, Speightstown finished a length and a half in front of Clock Stopper. 
 In the Sword Dancer, Better Talk Now, who is trained by Graham Motion, overtook Request for Parole and the pace-setting Balto Star in the stretch to win for the first time since last fall. Better Talk Now paid $17.80 on a $2 bet to win.
 Earlier on the card, a 2-year-old colt named Scipion out of A.P. Indy and the Strawberry Road mare, Strawberry Reason, displayed some of the promise that led him to be purchased for $1.9 million at last year's Fasig Tipton sales here. After trailing the eight-horse field by 12 lengths after a half-mile in his career debut, Scipion, who is trained by Patrick Biancone and was ridden by Javier Castellano, roared from last to first in the final furlong to win the second race, which was run at seven furlongs.

HEADLINE: Putting Out the Welcome Mat for Big Estate Homes

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST

 BODY:
THESE days, towns are not chasing after businesses and begging them to settle in their borders. They are lusting after the buyers of extremely large houses who pay property taxes to match.
 When a 12-acre hilltop area on the border between the Pocantico Hills and Tarrytown school districts in Westchester County was nothing but brush, for instance, no one much cared who collected the property taxes on it. But when a developer began building $2 million houses on the land and marketing them as the Legends at Pocantico Hills, Tarrytown school officials took notice. 
 That land was once in the Tarrytown school district, and the educators wanted it back. The 11-house Legends development is expected to generate $400,000 a year in property taxes, or about 1 percent of the Tarrytown schools' annual budget. 
 Back when developers were building tracts of ranch homes and cookie-cutter colonials, fighting to include a development within a school district's boundaries would have been unthinkable. Suburban homes, crammed with school-age children and taxed at less than the cost of educating them, were widely considered by planners to be financial losers. 
 But that was before ''estate'' homes, as big as hotels and as opulent as museums, turned the planning equation upside down. Their property taxes can rival or exceed those of small businesses.
 ''This is elementary arithmetic,'' said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. ''On average it costs a municipality about $10,000 a pupil for education. If you have two schoolchildren per house, you would need $20,000 just for the schools. Now, the average property tax is about 3 percent of the sales price, give or take. So the normal $300,000 to $500,000 house doesn't cover it. Houses that are $700,000 are right on the edge, on a fiscal impact basis.''
 In the second quarter of this year in Westchester alone, 593 houses were moneymakers from a tax point of view, all selling for more than $750,000 and the majority for more than $1 million. This fact was not lost on town decision makers.
 In Armonk, 27 ultraluxury homes are being built on six acres in a $50 million gated community. The property, the former Schultz's Cider Mill, was a farm stand with a cider shop that sold homemade doughnuts. It was commercially zoned and when it was first sold in 2000, an A. & P. supermarket was proposed to take its place. When neighbors complained that they didn't want the traffic or the smells that a supermarket would generate, the town agreed to change the zoning to residential use. The homes will sell for $1.5 million to $2.5 million. 
 ''I would venture to say that the taxes from that project would generate more than the A. & P. would have,'' said John A. Lombardi, town supervisor of North Castle, which includes the village of Armonk. ''But that is not why we changed the zoning. We changed the zoning because a lot of people were opposed to it.''
 The development, known appropriately as CiderMill, is not expected to add many children to the school district. A neighboring development of 55 homes, known as Whippoorwill Ridge, sends about a dozen children to the public schools, Mr. Lombardi said. 
 The Food Emporium in Armonk generates about $66,000 in property taxes, said Patricia Colombo, North Castle's receiver of taxes. The 27 homes at the CiderMill have not been assessed yet, but based on their expected sales price of $1.5 million to $2.5 million, their estimated taxes could be $21,000 to $35,000, according to Anna Maria Marrone, the North Castle assessor. The properties are expected to provide far more in taxes to the town than the proposed A. & P. would have. 
 There are negative aspects to these big tax producers, of course. Neighborhoods of expensive, gated houses bring little diversity, job opportunities and things to do, said Gerald Benjamin, a political scientist who serves on the Real Property Tax Administration System Alliance, a state-sponsored research group. 
 ''If you have exclusionary zoning with very large lots, the social consequences of that are problematic,'' said Dr. Benjamin, who is a dean at the State University of New York at New Paltz. 
 In seasonal communities the economic benefit of encouraging residential development can be even stronger. 
 In Long Beach Township, a summer community on the New Jersey shore, some commercial property this year has been redeveloped as luxury houses, causing an outcry among residents who fear that the character of their town is changing. The Colony movie theater and Mr. T's Amusements, both longtime landmarks, were torn down to make way for million-dollar homes.
 ''In a way this is enhancing the neighborhood,'' said DiAnne C. Gove, the mayor of Long Beach. ''It wasn't the only movie theater on the Island. The parking lot was dirty. It was unsightly. During the day, people parked there and used the beach. And the homes that are going up are beautiful.'' 
 The developer was able to build houses in each case because the property was zoned residential and commercial, Ms. Gove said. 
 ''Obviously, if you push it to the extreme and every commercial establishment is knocked down, it's not a good thing for the town,'' said Paul Gow, an agent with Long Beach Island Real Estate. ''What I see more of is knocking down older homes and building new palatial homes.''
 Since the dawn of Levittown, the holy grail of suburban planning has been a ''clean ratable,'' and in the 50's and 60's that was the office building, said Dr. Hughes of Rutgers. 
 ''It had no smokestack and no schoolchildren,'' he said. ''But in the 1970's and 80's, the traffic impact became a key concern. The hot item now is the ''active adult'' community, which is marketed to people 55 and older. It has no smokestack, no schoolchildren and no rush-hour traffic.''
 Not only are town officials eager to approve plans for active adult communities, but the largest bubble of baby boomers are just entering their downsizing years, so the potential market is huge, Dr. Hughes said.
 In Garden City, on Long Island, 25 acres of commercial property were rezoned into residential property this year to allow a developer to build an adult community.
 ''The reason was not taxes or the school district,'' said Frank S. Fish, a planning consultant for Buckhurst, Fish & Jacquemart, which has designed master plans for many New York suburbs, including Garden City. ''It was more of an environmental impact, quality of life decision,'' he said. 
 In Franklin Township, N.J., there are currently five active adult communities on the books, according to Brian D. Levine, the mayor. Two have been completed and three are in the planning stage.
 Franklin Township, which lies between urban New Brunswick and bucolic Princeton, is one of the fastest-growing communities in New Jersey, Mr. Levine said. Four years ago, voters approved a referendum to spend $20 million to preserve open space. The town bought some property outright and the development rights to many farms. Town officials also created a new zoning category, changing some land from a residential zone to an age-restricted active adult zone. 
 ''Senior villages are very attractive,'' Mr. Levine said. ''They mean lower maintenance costs for the town. They don't generate rush-hour traffic. They don't use the schools. If they are gated, they maintain their own roads. Maybe they use more police, more emergency services, but they pay for themselves.'' 
 The property owners in the Legends at Pocantico Hills are also likely to pay for themselves tax-wise, regardless of whether the court decides that the houses are in the Tarrytown school district or in Pocantico Hills. WCI Spectrum Communities, the developer, filed a lawsuit in New York State Supreme Court after a regional education official sided with the Tarrytown schools in the dispute. Spectrum had told its buyers that the development was in the small and exclusive Pocantico Hills district, not the larger and more diverse Tarrytown schools. A trial will be held later this month.

HEADLINE: A Big Block Party

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THERE is a little bit of everything on Main Street in Willimantic on the third Thursday of the month. 
 The Connecticut National Guard and toe rings, face painting and live music are typical of the eclectic offerings at the celebration, which as its name suggests is on the third Thursday of the month from May to October and stretches the four blocks from High Street at the upper end of Main to Jackson Street at the lower. 
 The festival seems a combination family barbecue, church bazaar and fall carnival, with musical performances and food booths. Jugglers, stilt-walkers and magicians roam the streets and poets stage original works. Babies ride in strollers, young couples walk arm-in-arm and senior citizens dance in the middle of the street. 
 ''I'm already thinking about people I can bring back with me next month,'' said Cindy P. Hubler of Stafford, who made her first trip to Willimantic in July, and found herself getting custom-made foot jewelry at Stepping Out Toe Rings. ''It's like an old-fashioned block party, with merchants.''
 Joan M. Bouchard of Lebanon was greeting people at the Northeast Coalition for Justice and Peace booth, handing out copies of a C.I.A. warfare manual and stickers that proclaimed, ''Regime Change Begins at Home.'' 
 ''This is a great venue for peace and justice activists,'' Ms. Bouchard said. ''You'd be surprised how many stickers end up on the cars here.''
 One block down, at Main and Church streets, Edy A. Torres, a staff sergeant with the Connecticut National Guard in Rockville, was running a makeshift recruiting station. He said he had about five serious prospects come through during a three-hour stretch, which he hoped would translate into two new enlistments.
 ''We're not looking for a grand slam here,'' Sergeant Torres said. 
 ''You can see 5,000 people here on a Thursday night,'' said Johnny Prytko, whose Good Times Band was one of the performers at July's event. ''This is the talk of a lot of towns in Connecticut. People love a street festival.'' So why don't more towns do it? ''It takes a group of really hard-working people, and that's difficult to find,'' Mr. Prytko said.
 ''It's a beautiful thing, to see so many different people come together,'' said Jean M. deSmet, one of the organizers, who came up with the idea during a failed campaign for Windham first selectman (Willimantic, with a population of about 16,000, is a borough of Windham). She decided to follow up on her campaign promise, and with her supporters set up Willimantic Renaissance, a nonprofit organization that funds the fairs through donations and revenues from a beer booth.
 ''The street fest is an economic development initiative, in our minds,'' Ms. deSmet said. ''We're trying to change people's perceptions of downtown, and I think it's working.''
 ''At first a lot of people thought we were going to be closing Main Street for three hours for 50 people. But we probably attracted about 2,000 to the first one, which I think surprised everyone,'' said Ms. deSmet. ''The second one we might have had 4,000. We probably had 6,000 in July, and if the weather is good this month we could have 8,000 people. August is usually our best turnout.''
 She said there is a core of about 15 people who are involved with the planning and organizing, and 30 more who show up to work on Third Thursday, which is why it works.
 ''The only problem we have is each time we get a new volunteer, he or she brings in a good idea, so it keeps getting bigger, but no easier,'' Ms. deSmet said laughing. ''But because of the volunteers, it costs us about $2,500 to $3,000 per month to put it on. It would probably take $70,000 if it was produced professionally.''
 The festival starts at 6 p.m., but a lot of people arrive an hour early or more to find parking. It officially ends at 9, but on a warm summer night people hang around for an hour or more to catch up.
 ''There have been amazingly few problems considering how many people come in here each month,'' said Police Chief Lisa Maruzo-Bolduc. ''It's a very well-behaved crowd, generally. The biggest problem is usually kids trying to ride bikes or skateboards through the crowd and running over people's toes.''
 Phil Smith, manager of Nasiff's for Sports at 745 Main Street, said he sees a huge increase in foot traffic on Third Thursday nights, but that doesn't translate into additional sales.
 ''People are here for the food booths and the bands,'' Mr. Smith said. ''In fact, some of our regulars avoid Third Thursday because they know it's going to be tough finding a parking space. But our hope is that people will see what Main Street has to offer and come back.''
 Some of the merchants realize a windfall. Keith D. Niziankiewicz, who owns Fanny McHenry's Hot Dogs at Main and Jackson, sets up a temporary grill in the middle of Main Street.
 ''If you're at a street festival you've got to have a hot dog,'' he said with a grin as he dropped two dozen foot-longs on the grill. On Third Thursdays he sells about eight bags of hot dogs, 42 to a bag, or 336. ''On a normal Thursday night, I might sell a couple of dozen.''

HEADLINE: Thinking About Living in the Valley? Better Hurry

BYLINE: By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA

 BODY:
CRAIG AND JAMIE DREZEK made unofficial housing history in Derby earlier this year when they bought a year-old Colonial-style house for $450,000, what area real estate experts said was the most expensive single-family house ever sold at the time in the city and, for that matter, some of the other communities in the Lower Naugatuck Valley. 
 While $450,000 won't buy a lot in Fairfield County, a price that high for a house in the Valley is a bit of an eye-opener. Long economically depressed as its factories closed, most of the area's municipalities had modest homes at reasonable prices. The six Valley communities, Ansonia, Derby, Shelton, Seymour, Oxford and Beacon Falls, were often where young couples went to buy their first homes.
 But as prices for houses have skyrocketed in surrounding areas, people are buying homes in the Valley, pushing the median single-family house in 2003 to $230,000, up 50 percent since 1997. In 2000, the U.S. Census recorded population of nearly 100,000, growth of about 7 percent from 1990. 
 While a housing report released this year found that the average commuting time of Valley residents is about 20 minutes, about 5 percent commute 60 minutes or more, almost double the number in 1990. It is no coincidence that the morning backups on the Merritt Parkway and Interstate 95 often begin where they connect with Route 8, the highway that cuts through the heart of the Valley, as residents head for their jobs in Southern Connecticut and New York. 
 So many new houses and condominiums are being built that citizen's groups have been forming to scrutinize proposals that come before planning and zoning commissions. In Seymour, which has already issued more building permits in 2004 than it did for all of last year, some residents unsuccessfully demanded that the town impose a moratorium on new subdivisions and impose stricter housing development regulations. 
 ''In many cases, the Valley is subsidizing the work force of Fairfield County,'' said Richard Knoll, president of TEAM Inc., a coalition of representatives from organizations that offer services to Valley residents. ''Thirty years ago, the majority of people who lived in the Valley worked in the Valley. The brass and rubber industries have left. Today, there's a significant shift in that many work outside the Valley because they can afford the housing here.''
 This shift is also creating a concern that young people who already live in the Valley will be priced out of the market. The report on the region's housing market released this year, ''Housing the Workforce: An Assessment of Housing in the All-America Valley,'' sponsored by the Lower Naugatuck Valley Regional Housing Coalition, found that the three leading indicators of what it calls ''housing-cost stress,'' -- house prices, rent payments, and the earnings needed to afford either -- are pricing Valley middle- or upper-middle-class households out of the market. 
 ''Being able to afford housing in the Lower Naugatuck Valley region is quickly becoming a major issue for households with surprisingly high levels of household income,'' the report states, highlighting workers such as police officers, firefighters, teachers and nurses. ''Further, the data show that housing-cost stress in 2003 in the Lower Naugatuck Valley region is occurring at household-income levels,'' about $40,000 to $50,000, that are higher than in the past.
 The report found that housing prices have grown three times faster than the average household income, making housing virtually unaffordable for some Valley residents. For instance, teachers in the Valley would have to spend about 74 percent of their incomes to buy the average-priced house in Ansonia, which is $153,000, and a police officer would have to spend 83 percent, the report said.
 ''The housing market has just exploded in the Valley,'' said Barbara DeGennaro, a Derby lawyer who does real-estate closings. ''I just had a client who bought a house in Shelton six years ago for $300,000 who just sold it for $500,000. On the other hand, some of my client base, which is made up of Valley people, say they can't afford to buy what they want here anymore. Houses in the Valley are way out of their price range.''
 Jaws are dropping at property transactions like the Drezek's nearly half-million-dollar home, said William C. Nimons of Ansonia, senior vice president of Naugatuck Valley Savings and Loan in Naugatuck. Mr. Nimons said he recently was involved in the sale of an Oxford lot on which a new house will be built for about $600,000.
 If somebody thought they were going to buy a house in the Valley for $200,000, they are going to find out that they are few and far between,'' he said. ''And, at this point, that type of house is probably going to need a lot of upgrades or improvements.''
 Mr. Drezek said that part of the reason he and his wife were able to afford their 4,300-square-foot house is that their previous house, a Colonial they bought for $190,000 in 1996 in Seymour, sold for $357,000 in 2003.
 ''At that time, I knew, based on what we had sold our house in Seymour for, that things were changing drastically in the Valley,'' said Mr. Drezek, who will begin his first year as principal of Derby High School later this month.
 The 2000 census found that the Valley's population increased 6,700, or about 7 percent, to 99,567 from the 1990 census. The 2000 census also shows that almost 40 percent of the Valley's population is in Shelton, the only Valley town in Fairfield County. The rest are in New Haven County. The Valley housing report said Shelton and Oxford contain the most undeveloped land in the region.
 Building permits have also jumped. Just through June, the six Valley communities had issued 52 percent more permits, 224, than for all of last year, when they issued 147. Oxford alone had issued 102 permits through June, up from 64 last year.
 James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Jersey and an author of the 2004 study, ''The Beginning of the End of Suburbia?'', said development was slowing in the areas closer to New York, such as Fairfield County, and people are now buying homes in outlying areas, willing to withstand longer commutes.
 ''One result is that development is being channeled back into older development areas, old urban places,'' he said. ''The secondary effect of that is the resulting spillover into the rural areas farther outside of the metropolitan region. The economic glory of these areas is long since passed. These cities will offer developments and housing that is more affordable.''
 The rate of new housing development is of such concern in the Valley that citizen groups are putting pressure on planning and zoning commissions.
 Nancy Steiner of Shelton is one of the founders of WE R-1, a group of Shelton residents fighting what they call the overdevelopment of housing. Ms. Steiner said the group was trying to change zoning laws to prevent the Planning and Zoning Commission ''from gobbling up our one-house-per-one-acre regulations'' to allow high-density, cluster housing in residential sections.
 ''When I moved here, Shelton was bucolic and the land was gorgeous and precious,'' she said. ''Now developers stand to make much larger profits on less land.''
 Mr. Nimons of the Naugatuck Valley Savings and Loan said he was seeing builders, developers, and real-estate companies buying older houses, rehabilitating them and putting them back on the market at prices 30 to 40 percent higher.
 ''They are pushing the first-time homeowner out of the market,'' he said. ''If only one of a couple is working, they are not going to be able to buy a house unless they have a substantial down payment.''
 Some solutions to the housing problem include renovating empty factory, school and historic buildings, updating older houses, improving public transportation, planning subdivisions better and offering incentives for developers, Mr. Knoll of TEAM said.
 The housing report suggests developing zoning policies that encourage the construction of affordable housing, such as exemptions for the number of units built on a parcel if 10 percent or more are deemed affordable. Another option is creating homebuyer programs intended to create incentives for people to buy houses either in or near the communities in which they work. Such a program would provide mortgages at below-market rates, down-payment assistance, closing-cost subsidies and mortgage insurance to qualified buyers.
 ''Each community is unique and has its own thoughts about smart growth,'' Mr. Knoll said. ''I'm particularly interested in an ordinance in Stamford that requires a developer to build one unit of affordable housing for every 10 units built.''
 Mr. Nimons said solutions would be difficult.
 ''I've been in the Valley all of my life and I've seen it all,'' Mr. Nimons said. ''I've never seen an environment where prices ratcheted up and didn't come back down. But even if the prices do come down 10 percent in our area, it's still not going to bring back affordable housing to the first-time homeowner.''
